From 2008 to 2016, the political orientations of Republican and Democratic voters showed notable shifts. Republican voters consistently favored a more conservative direction, with 60% in 2016 wanting the GOP to move in a more conservative direction, compared to 36% who preferred moderation. This trend has remained relatively stable since 2008, when 59% of Republican and Republican-leaning voters supported working with Obama, while 36% wanted their leaders to stand up to him [7][8].

![Republican voters have consistently favored a more conservative direction over time](image5)

Democratic voters, on the other hand, experienced a significant shift toward more liberal orientations. In 2008, only 33% of Democratic voters wanted the party to move in a more liberal direction, while 57% favored a more moderate approach. By 2016, this gap narrowed considerably, with 49% supporting a more liberal direction and 47% preferring moderation. This marks a significant increase in liberal sentiment compared to earlier years [9][10].

![Democratic voters have shifted toward a more liberal orientation over time](image3)

These trends illustrate a growing divide in political orientations, with Republicans maintaining a strong conservative stance and Democrats increasingly embracing more liberal positions.

In 2016, only 26% of Trump voters said he should appoint Democrats to his administration, while 52% believed it didn’t matter, and 21% said he should not. In contrast, in 2008, 52% of Obama voters thought he should appoint Republicans to his cabinet—double the share of Trump voters who supported appointing Democrats in 2016 [6, 8]. This suggests that Obama voters were more open to bipartisanship in appointments than Trump voters.  

![26% of Trump voters supported appointing Democrats in 2016](image2)  
![52% of Obama voters supported appointing Republicans in 2008](image4)  

Overall, voter opinions on appointing opposition party members show a significant difference, with greater support for bipartisanship during Obama’s election compared to Trump’s.

Perceptions of the U.S. military campaign against ISIS shifted notably from July to December 2015. In July, 55% of respondents believed the U.S. and its allies would "Definitely/Probably succeed," while 36% thought they would "Definitely/Probably fail." By December, optimism increased, with 66% believing the campaign would succeed and 27% expecting failure [3][7]. ![Increase in optimism regarding the U.S. military campaign success](image3)

However, assessments of how well the campaign was going remained negative. In July, 62% rated it as "Not too/at all well," slightly decreasing to 58% by December. Conversely, the percentage rating it as "Very/Fairly well" rose slightly from 30% in July to 35% in December [9][10]. ![Slight improvement in perceived effectiveness of the U.S. military campaign](image4)

In summary, while optimism about the campaign’s ultimate success grew, perceptions of its current effectiveness remained largely unchanged.

Perceptions of whether Islam encourages violence more than other religions have shown notable changes over time and vary significantly across political affiliations. Overall, public opinion has been closely divided, with 46% of Americans in December 2015 saying Islam is more likely to encourage violence, while 45% said it is not—a slight decline from 50% in September 2014 [4]. This trend is visualized in a line graph showing the fluctuation of these opinions from 2002 to 2015, with the gap between those who believe Islam encourages violence and those who do not narrowing over time ![Opinions on Islam and violence fluctuated from 2002 to 2015](image4).

Political affiliation plays a significant role in shaping these perceptions. Republicans are far more likely than Democrats to associate Islam with violence, with 68% of Republicans holding this view in December 2015, a historical high [6]. In contrast, only 30% of Democrats shared this opinion, down from 42% in September 2014 [6, 8]. This growing partisan divide is further highlighted in a line graph showing Republicans’ views increasing steadily from 33% in 2002 to 68% in 2015, while Democrats’ opinions decreased slightly over the same period ![Republicans’ views on Islam and violence increased significantly from 2002 to 2015](image5).

Ideological differences within parties are also stark. Among conservative Republicans, 77% believe Islam is more likely to encourage violence, while only 16% disagree [7]. Liberal Democrats, on the other hand, hold nearly the opposite view, with 73% saying Islam is no more likely to encourage violence than other religions [7]. These ideological divides are part of a broader trend where perceptions of Islam and violence have become increasingly polarized along political lines [1, 7].

Across demographic and religious groups, white evangelical Protestants are the most likely to associate Islam with violence, with 70% holding this view, compared to 49% of Catholics and 51% of white mainline Protestants [9]. Age also plays a role, with younger adults (18-29) being far less likely (32%) than older adults (51% of those 65+) to believe Islam encourages violence [2]. These trends are captured in a detailed table showing survey results across various demographic and political groups from 2014 to 2015 ![Survey results on perceptions of Islam and violence across demographic groups](image1).

In summary, perceptions of whether Islam encourages violence remain divided, with Republicans, conservatives, and older adults more likely to hold this view, while Democrats, liberals, and younger adults are less likely to do so. These opinions have become increasingly polarized over time.

Americans overwhelmingly consider the concept of machines performing jobs currently done by humans to be plausible, with 77% finding it at least somewhat realistic and 20% describing it as extremely realistic [7][8]. This perception varies with familiarity: those who have heard a lot about the idea are much more likely to see it as extremely realistic (48%) compared to those who have heard little (14%) or nothing (4%) [6]. ![Levels of familiarity with the concept](image2)

Public sentiment leans more toward worry than enthusiasm. While 33% express some level of enthusiasm, 72% are worried about this future scenario [3][9]. Notably, those with higher awareness are more enthusiastic (47%) compared to those with lower awareness (18%) [2][5]. ![Levels of enthusiasm and worry](image4)

Americans anticipate significant changes to jobs and work due to automation, with concerns about negative outcomes outweighing optimism about positive ones. For instance, 76% believe inequality between rich and poor will worsen, while only 25% think the economy will create many new, better-paying jobs [10]. ![Possible positive and negative outcomes of automation](image3)

Additionally, there is strong support for limiting automation to jobs that are dangerous or unhealthy, and moderate backing for measures like universal basic income [4]. However, most workers (85%) are not concerned about their own jobs being automated in their lifetimes [7]. ![Survey responses about the concept](image5)

In summary, while Americans generally find the idea of machines performing human jobs realistic, they are more worried than enthusiastic about its implications, particularly its potential to exacerbate inequality and disrupt employment.

Public opinions on limiting machine use in the workforce and replacing human jobs are varied but reveal a strong preference for regulation and cautious implementation. A majority of Americans (58%) believe there should be limits on the number of jobs businesses can replace with machines, even if machines perform better or are cheaper, as depicted in the pie chart `![Majority supports limits on job replacement by machines](image2)`. This sentiment is echoed in text, where 60% of Democrats and 54% of Republicans agree on the need for such limits [2][3].  

There is overwhelming support (85%) for limiting machines to dangerous or unhealthy jobs, with nearly half (47%) strongly favoring this policy [9][10]. This is further illustrated in the bar graph `![Strong support for limiting machines to dangerous jobs](image4)`, which shows 47% strongly favoring this approach. Policies like a universal basic income (60% in favor) and a national service program (58% in favor) also garner significant support as measures to mitigate the impact of automation on human workers [3][10].  

Despite these concerns, there is a division on whether businesses are justified in replacing humans with machines if it results in better and cheaper work, with 41% supporting this view [7]. Additionally, the public is evenly split on whether the government or individuals should be responsible for displaced workers [4].  

In summary, while there is strong support for limiting machines to certain roles and implementing protective policies, opinions are divided on the broader scope of automation and its impact on employment.

Perceptions of job availability show a notable partisan divide between Republicans and Democrats. Currently, 71% of Republicans say there are plenty of jobs available locally, compared to 53% of Democrats [3]. This gap has widened since October 2017, when 58% of Republicans and 47% of Democrats viewed jobs as widely available [3]. ![Perceptions of job availability vary by political affiliation](image1).

Republicans are more optimistic about job opportunities, with 71% believing jobs are plentiful, while only 23% say they are difficult to find. In contrast, 53% of Democrats see plenty of jobs, but 39% find them difficult to locate [3]. ![Perceptions of job availability vary by political affiliation](image1).

Interestingly, while overall perceptions of job availability have improved—60% of Americans now say there are plenty of jobs in their communities—this optimism is still divided along partisan lines, with Republicans consistently more positive than Democrats [4]. ![Perceptions of job availability vary by political affiliation](image1).

In summary, Republicans are significantly more likely than Democrats to perceive job availability as plentiful, reflecting broader partisan differences in economic outlooks.

In January 2018, **63% of Democrats** wanted their party’s leaders to “stand up” to President Trump, while in January 2019, this percentage increased to **70%** [6]. ![Democrats wanting leaders to stand up to Trump increased from 63% in 2018 to 70% in 2019](image3). 

Among Republicans, the share saying Trump should stand up to Democrats also rose, from **40% in January 2018** to **51% in January 2019** [6]. ![Republicans wanting Trump to stand up to Democrats increased from 40% in 2018 to 51% in 2019](image5). 

Both parties saw an increase in the desire for their leaders to take a stronger stance against the opposition during this period.

Perceptions of racial discrimination vary significantly between Latino Democrats and Republicans. According to the survey, **73% of Latino Democrats and Democratic leaners** believe that people not seeing racial discrimination where it really does exist is a bigger problem, compared to only **36% of Latino Republicans and Republican leaners** who share this view [6]. This stark difference is further emphasized in the bar graph, which shows that **73% of Democrats/Lean Democrats** feel that people not recognizing existing racial discrimination is a major issue, while **62% of Republicans/Lean Republicans** are more concerned about people seeing racial discrimination where it does not exist [image3].

Additionally, Latino Democrats are more likely to report experiencing racial discrimination themselves, with **75%** stating that not seeing racial discrimination is a significant problem for the country, compared to **36% of Latino Republicans**[10]. This divergence in perspectives underscores the influence of political affiliation on perceptions of racial issues within the Latino community. ![Perceptions of racial discrimination among Latino Democrats and Republicans](image3)

The underrepresentation of women, blacks, and Hispanics in STEM jobs is attributed to several key factors, as highlighted by the Pew Research Center. For women, major reasons include facing discrimination in recruitment, hiring, and promotion (39%) and not being encouraged to pursue STEM from an early age (39%)[5]. Additionally, challenges such as balancing work and family (33%) and a lack of female role models (24%) contribute to this disparity[5].

For blacks and Hispanics, the primary reasons are limited access to quality education to prepare them for STEM fields (42%) and a lack of encouragement to pursue STEM from an early age (41%)[5]. Other significant factors include facing discrimination in recruitment, hiring, and promotion (31%), a lack of black and Hispanic role models (27%), and a belief that they are less likely to succeed in STEM (33%)[5].

![Major reasons why more women, blacks, and Hispanics are not in STEM jobs](image5)

Blacks in STEM positions, in particular, emphasize limited access to quality education, discrimination in recruitment and promotions, and a lack of encouragement from an early age as major underlying reasons for this underrepresentation[8]. Furthermore, 72% of black STEM employees believe discrimination in recruiting, hiring, and promotions is a major reason for the underrepresentation of blacks and Hispanics in STEM jobs, compared to only 27% of whites and 28% of Asians[7].

The perceived quality of education also plays a role, as only 25% of respondents believe K-12 public schools are "Best in the world/above average," while 51% of STEM postgraduate degree holders attribute their success to graduate education being "Best in the world/above average"[image1][image3]. This suggests that disparities in educational quality and access significantly impact minority representation in STEM fields.

U.S. adults and STEM postgraduate degree holders share a generally critical view of K-12 public school education, particularly in STEM subjects, but STEM degree holders are even more skeptical. Among U.S. adults, 25% consider K-12 STEM education to be at least above average compared to other developed nations, while 43% rate it as average and 30% see it as below average [4][7]. ![Perceptions of K-12 education quality](image5)

However, STEM postgraduate degree holders are significantly less positive. Only 13% of this group rate K-12 STEM education as above average, while 51% believe it is below average [1][9]. This stark contrast highlights that those with advanced STEM expertise are more critical of the quality of K-12 STEM education in the U.S. ![STEM degree holders' perceptions of K-12 education](image4)

Both groups, though, align in their overall lack of confidence in K-12 STEM education compared to other developed nations, with most viewing it as average or worse [8][10].

The trends of median investments in Europe and the U.S. from 2004 to 2009 reveal distinct patterns across different investment stages. In the U.S., **Seed**, **First**, **Second**, and **Later** stage investments all peaked around 2006-2007 before declining sharply by 2009. For instance, **Later** stage investments in the U.S. started below €8M in 2004, peaked around 2007, and then dropped to nearly €6M by 2009. Similarly, **Second** stage investments peaked around 2006/2007 and declined to below €4M by 2009 ![U.S. investment stages peaked in 2006-2007 and declined by 2009](image2).

In Europe, the trend was less pronounced but followed a similar pattern, with **Later** stage investments also peaking around 2007-2008. However, **Seed**, **First**, and **Second** stage investments in Europe showed more stability, with **Seed** investments remaining around €2M throughout the period ![European later-stage investments peaked around 2007-2008](image5). Notably, European investments were generally lower in magnitude compared to the U.S., reflecting the region's lower entry valuations and tighter control of cash invested [4]. This difference underscores the higher capital efficiency in Europe, driven by the scarcity of venture capital funds [1]. Overall, both regions experienced a post-bubble decline in investment activity by 2009, but the U.S. saw more significant fluctuations, while Europe maintained a steadier, albeit lower, investment trend.

The levels of confidence and likelihood in the document are evaluated based on expert assessment, the quality and quantity of available evidence, and the degree of consensus among studies. Confidence is expressed qualitatively and ranges from **low confidence** (inconclusive evidence or expert disagreement) to **very high confidence** (strong evidence and high consensus) [9]. For example, **very high confidence** indicates strong evidence with established theory, multiple sources, and consistent results, as shown in the confidence chart ![{Confidence levels chart}](image2).

Likelihood, on the other hand, is described probabilistically, with specific terms such as **very likely** (greater than or equal to a 9 in 10 chance) or **very unlikely** (less than or equal to a 1 in 10 chance) [3]. This is visually represented in the probability chart ![{Likelihood probability chart}](image3). Both confidence and likelihood levels are determined through a rigorous process where chapter author teams assess literature, evaluate evidence quality, and reach expert consensus [5].

Perceptions of political parties’ ethics and extremism vary significantly across educational and political affiliation groups. Among those with at least a college degree, 31% say neither the Republican nor the Democratic Party has high ethical standards, while 43% believe it describes one party but not the other, and 17% think it applies to both [3]. Independents are more critical, with 34% saying neither party has high ethical standards, compared to 19% of Republicans and 18% of Democrats [7]. ![Perceptions of ethical standards by education and affiliation](image4)

When it comes to extremism, more Americans view the Republican Party as "too extreme" (48%) than the Democratic Party (42%) [9]. This perception is consistent across partisan lines, with about three-quarters of each party viewing the opposing party as too extreme, while only about two-in-ten see their own party this way [4]. ![Comparison of extremism perceptions between parties](image2)

These differences are further highlighted in demographic breakdowns, where political affiliation plays a significant role in shaping these views. For example, among registered voters, party preference varies widely by gender, race, and education level, with Democrats leading among women, Black, Hispanic, and younger voters, while Republicans fare better among men, white voters, and those with less formal education [image3]. ![Demographic breakdown of party preference](image3)

In summary, perceptions of ethics and extremism are deeply polarized, with education and political affiliation significantly influencing how individuals view the Republican and Democratic parties.

Perceptions of ethical standards and extremism between the Republican and Democratic parties vary significantly, with education and political affiliation playing key roles in shaping these views. 

About four-in-ten Americans say each party has high ethical standards (42% for the Democratic Party and 41% for the GOP) [2]. However, a quarter of the public believes neither party meets this standard, with this view more prevalent among those with a college degree (31%) compared to those with some college (26%) or a high school diploma or less (20%) [5][8]. Independents are particularly critical, with 34% saying neither party has high ethical standards, compared to 19% of Republicans and 18% of Democrats [1]. 

![Bar chart showing perceptions of ethical standards and extremism by group](image1)

When it comes to extremism, more Americans view the Republican Party as “too extreme” (48%) than the Democratic Party (42%) [3]. This perception has declined for the GOP since last June (from 54%) but remains higher than for Democrats [3]. Partisan divides are stark: about three-quarters of Republicans and Democrats view the opposing party as too extreme, while only about two-in-ten in each party say the same about their own [7]. 

![Bar chart comparing perceptions of the Republican and Democratic parties](image3)

Political affiliation also heavily influences these views. Majorities of Republicans (66%) and Democrats (64%) believe their own party has high ethical standards, but only about two-in-ten in each party say the same about the opposing party [4][7].  

In summary, while ethical standards are viewed similarly for both parties, the GOP is seen as more extreme. Education and political affiliation significantly shape these perceptions, with independents and college-educated individuals more likely to critique both parties.

Perceptions of ethical standards and political party preferences show notable variations across different education levels and political affiliations. 

![A bar chart comparing political party preferences among various education levels](image5)  
Among registered voters, those with postgraduate degrees strongly favor the Democratic Party (62% to 30%), while those with a four-year college degree also lean Democratic (53% to 40%), as evident in this chart [2]. Preferences are more divided among those without a college degree, with high school graduates slightly favoring the Republican Party (47% to 42%) [2].

![A bar chart comparing perceptions of ethical standards across education levels and political affiliations](image3)  
When it comes to ethical standards, nearly a third (31%) of college graduates believe neither party has high ethical standards, while this view is less common among those with some college (26%) or only a high school education (20%) [1][7][9]. Independents are significantly more likely than partisans to hold this view, with 34% saying neither party meets this standard, compared to 19% of Republicans and 18% of Democrats [10].  

![A bar chart comparing perceptions of the Republican and Democratic parties' ethical standards](image2)  
The Democratic Party is slightly more likely to be viewed as having high ethical standards (42%) compared to the Republican Party (41%), though this difference is marginal [2]. However, partisans generally view their own party more positively, with 66% of Republicans and 64% of Democrats believing their respective parties have high ethical standards [5].  

These findings highlight how education and political affiliation shape both party preferences and perceptions of ethical standards, with higher education often correlating with Democratic leanings and greater skepticism toward both parties' ethics.

Public confidence in Trump’s handling of economic policy has seen a slight increase, with 53% expressing at least some confidence in May 2018, compared to 46% in January 2018 [3][10]. This is reflected in a line graph showing a steady rise from 46% in January to 53% in May ![Public confidence in Trump’s economic policy steadily increased from January to May 2018](image3).

In contrast, perceptions of Trump’s ethical standards remain deeply divided along partisan lines. Only 41% of Americans believe the GOP has high ethical standards, and a similar 42% say the same about the Democratic Party [2]. Among Republicans, 75% give the administration high marks for ethical standards, while 86% of Democrats rate them negatively [5]. This stark divide is visualized in a bar chart where 75% of Rep/Lean Rep respondents rate ethical standards as "Excellent," compared to 86% of Dem/Lean Dem respondents rating them as "Poor" ![Republicans rate Trump’s ethical standards highly, while Democrats overwhelmingly rate them poorly](image1).

Overall, while there is a modest increase in confidence in Trump’s economic policy, perceptions of his ethical standards remain highly polarized, with Republicans viewing them positively and Democrats negatively.

Public opinions regarding Trump's ability to handle economic policy and international crises have shown noticeable shifts over time, with significant differences between partisan perspectives. 

Starting with economic policy, public confidence has increased since January 2018, rising from 46% to 53% by May 2018 [7]. This trend is also reflected in the line graphs, which show a steady climb in the percentage of people who believe Trump can make good decisions about economic policy [image1]. However, overall public confidence in Trump's economic policy remains divided, with 53% expressing at least some confidence and 46% having little or no confidence [6].

When it comes to handling international crises, public confidence has also seen an uptick since January, rising from 35% to 43% by May 2018 [10]. The line graphs depict this recovery after a decline from 48% in April 2017 to a low of 35% in January 2018 [image1]. Despite this improvement, a narrow majority (54%) still expresses little or no confidence in Trump's ability to handle international crises [9].

Partisan perspectives play a significant role in shaping these opinions. Republicans have grown notably more confident in Trump’s ability to handle international crises, with confidence levels rising from 73% in January to 84% by May 2018 [5]. Similarly, economic policy sees strong support among Republicans, with 53% expressing at least some confidence [6]. Democrats, on the other hand, are far less favorable, as shown in the bar charts where only 5% of Democrats/Lean Dems “like” Trump overall, while 85% “don’t like” him [image3]. 

These partisan divides are further highlighted in the bar charts, which show stark contrasts in how Republicans and Democrats rate Trump’s effectiveness across various tasks, including economic policy and handling international crises [image4]. For instance, 75% of Republicans rate Trump’s performance as “excellent,” while 86% of Democrats rate it as “poor” [image5]. 

In summary, public confidence in Trump’s ability to handle economic policy and international crises has improved since January 2018, but remains deeply divided along partisan lines, with Republicans expressing strong support and Democrats showing significant skepticism.

Public confidence in Trump’s ability to handle economic policy and international crises has seen notable changes over time. Since January 2018, confidence in his handling of economic policy has increased from 46% to 53% [4], while his ability to manage an international crisis has risen from 35% to 43% [10]. These trends are visually reinforced by the line graphs in ![Public confidence in Trump’s abilities over time](image2), which show steady improvements in these areas since early 2018.  

When comparing political affiliations, Republican sentiment towards Trump’s conduct remains largely positive, with 38% liking his behavior and 45% having mixed feelings [6]. Democrats, however, overwhelmingly disapprove of his conduct, with 85% expressing dislike [1]. This divide is further illustrated in ![Republican and Democrat opinions on Trump’s conduct](image5), which visually contrasts the stark differences in sentiment between the two groups.  

Overall, while confidence in Trump’s economic and international crisis management has grown, partisan divides in views of his conduct remain deeply entrenched. ![Public confidence trends in Trump’s abilities](image2) highlights these shifts, while ![Republican and Democrat opinions on Trump’s conduct](image5) underscores the polarized nature of his approval.  
In summary, public confidence in Trump’s economic and crisis management skills has improved since January, but his conduct continues to polarize Republicans and Democrats.

Public confidence in Trump’s ability to handle an international crisis has seen fluctuations over time. In April 2017, 48% of the public had at least some confidence in his ability to handle such a crisis, but this declined to a low of 35% in January 2018 before rising to 43% by May 2018 [5]. ![Public confidence in handling an international crisis fluctuated, reaching 43% in May 2018](image3). 

In contrast, public confidence in Trump’s ability to make good decisions about economic policy has increased steadily. In January 2018, 46% expressed confidence, which rose to 53% by May 2018 [3]. ![Confidence in economic policy decisions rose from 46% in January 2018 to 53% in May 2018](image3).

Overall, while confidence in Trump’s handling of an international crisis remains lower than its peak in April 2017, it has recovered somewhat since January 2018. Meanwhile, confidence in his economic decision-making has shown consistent growth over the same period.

Over time, opinions among Republicans and Democrats regarding Trump's conduct and the ethical standards of his administration have shown some shifts but remain deeply polarized. 

Among **Republicans**, while **38%** say they like the way Trump conducts himself as president, **45%** have mixed feelings, and **16%** do not like it [3]. Conservative Republicans are more likely to approve of his conduct (**44%**) compared to moderate or liberal Republicans (**25%**), with **32%** of the latter expressing disapproval [6]. Additionally, **80%** of Republicans and Republican-leaners now say they agree with Trump on many or all issues, a significant increase from August 2017 [7]. However, opinions on the ethical standards of Trump administration officials vary by ideology: **15%** of conservative Republicans hold negative views, while **36%** of moderate and liberal Republicans rate the ethical standards as poor [1][10]. ![Republicans' opinions on Trump's conduct and ethical standards are divided by ideology.](image2)

Among **Democrats**, **85%** consistently say they do not like Trump’s conduct, with **10%** having mixed feelings and just **5%** approving [2][5]. This disapproval remains largely unchanged since August 2017 [4]. Similarly, **93%** of liberal Democrats give low marks to the ethical standards of the Trump administration, compared to **8%** of conservative or moderate Democrats [8]. ![Democrats overwhelmingly disapprove of Trump's conduct and ethical standards.](image1)

In summary, Republicans have shown increased agreement with Trump on policy issues, but their views on his conduct and ethical standards remain mixed. Democrats, on the other hand, continue to overwhelmingly disapprove of both his conduct and the ethical standards of his administration. ![Both Republicans and Democrats show deep divides in opinions on Trump's conduct and ethical standards.](image3)

Approval ratings of the Trump administration officials' ethical standards are significantly lower compared to past administrations. Only 39% of Americans rate the ethical standards of Trump administration officials as excellent or good, while 58% rate them as not good or poor [1][9]. This is notably lower than ratings for administrations dating back to Ronald Reagan’s, as the question was first asked in 1983 [1]. ![Trump administration’s ethical standards trail past administrations](image1)

Public approval of Trump’s job performance has remained relatively consistent, with ratings roughly on par with those at the outset of his presidency [2]. Interestingly, there is a strong correlation between disapproval of Trump’s job performance and negative views of his administration’s ethical standards. Among those who disapprove of Trump’s job performance, 42% do so very strongly, reflecting intense dissatisfaction [4]. ![Disapproval and approval ratings among different demographic groups](image2)

Demographic factors also play a role. For instance, there is an 18-point gender gap in approval ratings, with 48% of men approving of Trump’s performance compared to just 30% of women [5]. Additionally, younger adults, those with higher education levels, and non-whites are more likely to disapprove of Trump’s job performance [10]. ![Opinions among Republicans and Democrats in May 2018 and August 2017](image5)

In summary, the Trump administration’s ethical standards are rated lower than those of past administrations, and this dissatisfaction is reflected in the public’s approval of Trump’s job performance, with significant demographic and ideological divides influencing these views.

Educational levels and political affiliations significantly shape perceptions of ethical standards and approval ratings of Trump, as evidenced by the data.  

Among those with at least a college degree, 31% believe that neither the Republican nor the Democratic Party has high ethical standards, while 17% think both parties do [6]. This contrasts with those who have some college experience (26%) or only a high school degree or less (20%), who are less likely to hold this view [1]. ![Perceptions of ethical standards by education level](image4)  

Political affiliation also plays a critical role. Independents are more likely than partisans to say neither party has high ethical standards, with 34% holding this view, including equal shares of Republican and Democratic leaners (33% each) [10]. In contrast, only about 19% of Republicans and 18% of Democrats share this sentiment [10]. Additionally, while 67% of independent Republican leaners rate the Trump administration’s ethical standards as excellent or good, 88% of Democratic-leaning independents rate them as not good or poor [2]. ![Views on ethical standards by political affiliation](image3)  

Approval ratings of Trump also vary by education and political affiliation. Younger adults, those with higher education levels, and non-whites are more likely to disapprove of Trump’s performance [8]. Among political groups, 65% of independents overall view the administration’s ethical standards negatively, while Republicans and Democrats are more polarized in their assessments [2]. ![Disapproval and approval ratings across demographics](image2)  

In summary, higher education correlates with skepticism toward both parties’ ethical standards, while political affiliation drives polarization in views of Trump’s ethical performance and approval ratings. Independents are more critical of both parties’ ethics compared to partisans.

Voter reactions to the 2016 U.S. presidential election differed significantly from previous elections in both emotional tone and overall satisfaction. In 2016, 50% of voters were happy with Donald Trump’s victory, while 48% were unhappy, which is similar to the 2012 election where 52% were happy with Barack Obama’s reelection. However, these reactions were less positive compared to Obama’s first win in 2008, when 58% expressed happiness [5][6].

Emotionally, Trump’s election elicited a mix of reactions. The most prevalent emotions among all voters were **hopeful** (51%) and **uneasy** (53%) [2]. This contrasts with the more positive emotions felt after Obama’s 2008 victory, where 69% of voters felt hopeful and only 35% felt uneasy. The stark difference in emotional reactions can be attributed to the polarized nature of the 2016 campaign, which many voters described as more negative and less issue-focused than previous elections [7][4].

![Voter emotions after the 2016 election](image2)

Additionally, the emotional divide between Trump and Clinton voters was pronounced. Trump voters overwhelmingly felt **hopeful** (96%) and **proud** (74%), while Clinton voters reported feelings of **uneasy** (90%), **sad** (77%), **scared** (76%), and **angry** (62%). These stark contrasts reflect the deep polarization of the 2016 electorate [5].

![Emotional reactions of Trump and Clinton voters](image5)

Surprise was another dominant reaction, with 73% of all voters expressing astonishment at Trump’s victory. This included 87% of Clinton voters and 60% of Trump voters, highlighting the unexpected nature of the election outcome [10].

![Levels of surprise among voter groups](image4)

In summary, voter reactions in 2016 were more polarized and emotionally charged compared to previous elections, with feelings of hope and unease being most prevalent, alongside widespread surprise.

The emotional reactions to Trump's election differ starkly between Trump and Clinton voters. ![Trump voters felt hopeful and proud, while Clinton voters felt uneasy, sad, scared, and angry.](image5) Among Trump voters, 96% felt hopeful and 74% felt proud, whereas Clinton voters expressed predominantly negative emotions: 90% felt uneasy, 77% felt sad, 76% felt scared, and 62% felt angry. Only 7% of Clinton voters felt hopeful, and a mere 1% felt proud [1][3][5][8].

Expectations of Trump’s first term also varied significantly between the two groups. ![More voters expected Trump’s first term to be successful compared to unsuccessful, but optimism was lower than for Obama in 2008.](image2) Overall, 56% of voters expected Trump’s first term to be successful, while 39% expected it to be unsuccessful. This optimism, however, was less than the 67% who expected Obama’s first term to be successful in 2008 [4]. ![Clinton voters were overwhelmingly pessimistic about Trump’s first term, with 76% expecting it to be unsuccessful.](image4) In contrast, only 15% of Clinton voters thought Trump’s first term would be successful, compared to 76% who expected it to be unsuccessful. This pessimism was more pronounced than the 39% of McCain supporters who thought Obama’s first term would be successful in 2008 [10].

In summary, Trump voters were largely hopeful and proud about his election and optimistic about his first term, while Clinton voters expressed deep unease, sadness, fear, and anger, with overwhelming pessimism about his presidency.

Perspectives on the potential success of Trump’s first term and the willingness to give him a chance vary significantly between Trump and Clinton voters. 

An overwhelming **97%** of Trump voters expect his first term to be successful, a sentiment comparable to the **92%** of Obama voters in 2008 [6]. This optimism is also reflected in their confidence about his presidency, with **88%** expressing confidence and only **10%** having serious concerns ![This image shows 88% of Trump voters are confident about his presidency](image1). Additionally, **84%** of Trump voters believe he will give equal priority to the needs of all Americans, highlighting their trust in his leadership ![This image shows 84% of Trump voters believe he will prioritize all Americans equally](image2).

In contrast, Clinton voters hold largely negative views. Only **15%** believe Trump’s first term will be successful, with **76%** expecting it to be unsuccessful [4]. Their skepticism is further emphasized by the fact that **75%** think Trump will prioritize the needs of his own supporters over all Americans ![This image shows 75% of Clinton voters think Trump will prioritize his supporters](image2). While **58%** of Clinton voters say they are willing to give Trump a chance, **39%** outright reject the idea, citing his character as a barrier ![This image shows 39% of Clinton voters refuse to give Trump a chance](image3).

Overall, Trump voters are highly optimistic about his presidency, while Clinton voters are predominantly pessimistic and less willing to extend him the benefit of the doubt.

Trump and Clinton voters have markedly different priorities for Trump’s presidency, reflecting their contrasting views on his leadership. Health care is the top priority for 29% of Trump voters, compared to just 12% of Clinton voters. Among Trump voters, there is a strong focus on repealing the Affordable Care Act, while Clinton voters emphasize maintaining or fixing it [1], [6]. ![Health care is a top priority for Trump voters, but less so for Clinton voters.](image1)

The economy and immigration are also significant priorities for Trump voters, with 15% naming each as a top issue, compared to 9% and 6% of Clinton voters, respectively. This suggests that Trump voters are more aligned with his campaign promises to bolster the economy and tighten immigration policies [6]. ![Economy and immigration are more important to Trump voters than Clinton voters.](image1)

On the other hand, Clinton voters prioritize unifying the country (12%) and changing Trump’s personal behavior (11%), reflecting concerns about the divisive nature of his campaign [8], [10]. ![Unifying the country and addressing personal behavior are higher priorities for Clinton voters.](image1)

Clinton voters are also more likely to express uncertainty about Trump’s goals, with 84% saying his vision is not clear, compared to just 12% of Trump voters who feel the same [5], [9]. ![Clinton voters are more uncertain about Trump’s goals than Trump voters.](image2)

Overall, these differences highlight a deep divide: Trump voters are focused on policy changes aligned with his campaign, while Clinton voters emphasize unity and transparency, underscoring their skepticism about his leadership. ![Trump and Clinton voters have starkly different priorities and views on Trump’s leadership.](image3)

Trump and Clinton voters show stark differences in their confidence in Trump’s handling of foreign policy and their expectations for race relations post-election.  

![Trump voters express high confidence in Trump on foreign policy, with 47% having a great deal of confidence and 44% a fair amount](image1)  
Among Trump voters, 47% have a great deal of confidence in Trump’s handling of foreign policy, and 44% have a fair amount, totaling 91% with at least some confidence [7]. Conversely, Clinton voters are overwhelmingly skeptical, with 63% expressing no confidence at all and 29% having only a fair amount [4].  

![Clinton voters expect race relations to worsen, with 84% predicting negative outcomes, while Trump voters are more optimistic, with 50% expecting improvement](image3)  
Expectations for race relations post-election also diverge sharply. While 50% of Trump voters believe race relations will improve, 38% think there will be no change, and only 9% expect them to worsen [1]. In contrast, 84% of Clinton voters predict race relations will get worse, 13% see no change, and just 2% expect improvement [5].  

These differences highlight the polarized views between Trump and Clinton voters on both Trump’s policy competence and the societal impact of his election.

Trump and Clinton voters exhibit starkly different levels of confidence in Trump’s ability to improve race relations and political cooperation. Among Trump voters, **50%** believe that race relations will improve under Trump, while only **9%** think they will worsen, with **38%** expecting no change [9]. In contrast, **84%** of Clinton voters anticipate that race relations will deteriorate, while just **2%** think they will improve, and **13%** expect no difference [1][5]. This divergence is visually represented in the bar chart, which highlights the optimism among Trump voters and the pessimism among Clinton voters regarding race relations. ![Bar chart comparing opinions on race relations under Trump and Obama](image1)

Similarly, when it comes to political cooperation, Trump voters are more optimistic. **47%** of Trump voters believe partisan relations will improve, compared to only **9%** who think they will worsen [8]. Clinton voters, on the other hand, are more skeptical, with **43%** expecting partisan relations to worsen, compared to **10%** who think they will improve [5]. ![Bar chart showing perceptions of change in political cooperation in 2016](image5)

In summary, Trump voters are significantly more confident in Trump’s ability to improve both race relations and political cooperation, while Clinton voters are overwhelmingly pessimistic about these outcomes.

Voters’ expectations of race relations and partisan relations after the 2016 election reveal stark contrasts, influenced by partisan divides and perceptions of leadership. A significant portion of voters, 46%, expected race relations to worsen under Trump, while only 25% anticipated improvement [1][3]. This pessimism was particularly pronounced among Clinton voters, with 84% expecting race relations to deteriorate, while Trump voters were more optimistic, with 50% expecting improvement and only 9% predicting worsening relations [1][5]. ![Voters were pessimistic about race relations improving under Trump, with 46% expecting worse conditions](image4)

In contrast, expectations for partisan relations were mixed. Only 27% of voters believed relations between the two parties would improve, while an equal percentage expected them to worsen, and 45% anticipated no change [8]. Trump voters were slightly more optimistic, with 47% expecting improvement, though Clinton voters were more likely to predict worsening relations, with 43% holding this view [9]. ![Expectations for partisan relations were divided, with 27% of voters anticipating improvement and 27% expecting worse relations](image5)

Perceptions of enthusiastic supporters also shaped voter expectations. While 73% of all voters disagreed that highly enthusiastic supporters of a president would lead to less getting done, this view varied significantly by voter group. Trump voters were more divided, with 55% disagreeing and 37% agreeing, whereas Clinton voters overwhelmingly disagreed, with 90% rejecting the notion [3]. ![Most voters, especially Clinton supporters, disagreed that enthusiastic supporters would hinder progress](image3)

Overall, voters expressed more pessimism about race relations than partisan relations under Trump, and the perceived impact of enthusiastic supporters highlighted the deep partisan divide in expectations for governance.

The political orientations of Democratic and Republican voters have shown distinct shifts over time, particularly in the years leading up to the 2016 election. 

For **Republican and Republican-leaning voters**, a consistent preference for a more conservative direction has been evident. In November 2016, 60% desired their party to move in a more conservative direction, while 36% favored moderation. This trend has remained stable since 2008, with minimal fluctuations in the percentages [4]. ![Republican voters consistently favor a conservative direction](image2).

In contrast, **Democratic and Democratic-leaning voters** have seen a notable shift toward a more liberal orientation. In November 2016, 49% supported moving in a more liberal direction, compared to 47% favoring moderation. This represents a significant increase from previous years; for example, in 2012 and 2008, only about a third of Democratic voters supported a more liberal stance [7]. ![Democratic voters increasingly support a liberal direction](image3).

Reactions to the 2016 election outcomes further highlight these partisan divides. Among **Trump voters**, 94% were happy that the Republican Party retained control of Congress, while **Clinton voters** were overwhelmingly unhappy (87%) [8]. ![Trump voters are overwhelmingly happy with GOP control, while Clinton voters are unhappy](image5). Additionally, partisan polarization has grown, with Democrats now far more supportive of their party moving leftward compared to post-2008 or post-2012 elections [7].

In summary, Republican voters have consistently favored conservatism, while Democratic voters have shifted significantly toward liberalism, reflecting growing polarization that was further highlighted by their reactions to the 2016 election outcomes.

In 2008, there was a strong inclination towards bipartisan cooperation after Barack Obama’s election. Nearly eight-in-ten (78%) of Obama’s voters and 76% of McCain’s voters believed that their party’s leaders should work with the opposing party, even at the risk of disappointing their supporters [9]. Additionally, 59% of Republicans and Republican-leaning voters supported their leaders working with Obama, while 36% preferred standing up to him [10]. This sentiment is further illustrated in the survey results from November 2008, where 74% of all voters favored Republican leaders working with Obama, compared to only 22% who wanted them to stand up to him ![November 2008 survey results](image1).

In contrast, the 2016 election saw a starkly different dynamic. While 59% of all voters still supported Democratic leaders working with President Trump, this was a significant drop from the 74% who favored cooperation in 2008. Among Democrats and Democratic-leaning voters, only 32% supported working with Trump, while 65% preferred standing up to him on key issues, even if it meant less progress in Washington [4]. Republicans and Republican-leaning voters, on the other hand, overwhelmingly supported cooperation, with 84% favoring working with Trump and only 14% advocating standing up to him ![November 2016 survey results](image1).

The shift in voter expectations reflects a more polarized political climate in 2016 compared to 2008. Democratic voters were far less willing to compromise with the newly elected president, while Republicans were more supportive of cooperation with Trump than they had been with Obama.

The 2016 election was marked by overwhelmingly negative perceptions of political entities and a sense of heightened campaign negativity. Voters viewed the campaign as extraordinarily negative, with 92% stating there was more “mudslinging” or negative campaigning than in past elections, a 20-point increase from the previous high in 2004 [7][9]. ![The perception of more mudslinging in elections has steadily increased, peaking at 92% in 2016.](image1)

This negativity extended to the evaluations of key political actors. Only 22% of voters gave the Republican Party an A or B grade, while 26% gave the Democratic Party a similar rating. Both parties received failing grades from about 30% of voters, the highest since 1988 [5]. Similarly, the press and pollsters were graded poorly, with 22% and 21% respectively receiving A or B grades, and failing grades given by 38% and 30% [3]. ![Key political entities received low grades, with the press and pollsters being particularly harshly judged.](image4)

Voters also expressed a range of strong emotions about the election. While 51% felt hopeful about Trump’s victory, 53% felt uneasy, and 41% each felt sad or scared [6][1]. Clinton voters were particularly distressed, with 90% feeling uneasy and 76% scared, while Trump voters reported high levels of hope (96%) and pride (74%) [1]. ![Voter emotions about the election varied widely, with significant feelings of unease and hope.](image3)

The dissatisfaction with campaign conduct and the entities involved reflects a broader perception of negativity and dysfunction in the 2016 election. Voters graded themselves critically as well, with only 40% giving “the voters” an A or B grade, the lowest since 1996 [4]. In summary, the 2016 election was characterized by widespread voter dissatisfaction with political entities and an unprecedented sense of campaign negativity.

The emotional reactions of Trump and Clinton voters following the 2016 election were sharply divided, reflecting the polarized nature of the campaign and its outcome. Among Trump voters, the predominant emotions were positive, with **96% feeling hopeful** and **74% feeling proud** about his victory [6]. Many Trump supporters also expressed **happiness** and **surprise**, as the unexpected nature of the result was a recurring theme [4]. ![Trump voters expressed happiness and surprise, while Clinton voters felt shocked and disappointed.](image3)

In contrast, Clinton voters overwhelmingly reported negative emotions, with **90% feeling uneasy**, **77% feeling sad**, and **76% feeling scared** about Trump’s victory [6]. The most common reactions among Clinton voters were **shock**, **disappointment**, and **disgust**, with many expressing disbelief at the outcome [8]. ![Clinton voters felt uneasy, sad, and scared, while Trump voters felt hopeful and proud.](image5)

These emotional reactions correlate with the broader perception of the campaign’s tone and Trump’s performance. The 2016 election was widely viewed as **extraordinarily negative**, with **92% of voters** saying there was more “mudslinging” compared to past elections [7]. ![The 2016 election saw the highest perception of mudslinging at 92%.](image1) Additionally, Trump received **low grades** for his conduct during the campaign, with only **30% giving him an A or B** and an **average grade of C-** [3]. ![Trump received low grades for his performance, with an average grade of C-.](image4)

The high levels of negativity and mudslinging likely exacerbated the emotional divide between Trump and Clinton supporters, contributing to the starkly different reactions to the election outcome.

The emotional reactions to Trump's victory reveal stark contrasts between Trump and Clinton voters, reflecting their divergent expectations prior to the election. Among Trump voters, the dominant emotions were "Happy" and "Surprised," with 60% expressing surprise and many describing their reaction as "happy" [3][8]. ![Trump voters' emotions are primarily happy and surprised](image3). This suggests that while many Trump supporters were pleased with the outcome, a significant portion did not fully anticipate his victory, highlighting the widespread unpredictability of the election.

In contrast, Clinton voters overwhelmingly described their reactions as "Shocked," "Disappointed," and "Disgusted" [7][8]. ![Clinton voters' reactions are largely shocked, disappointed, and disgusted](image3). Additionally, 87% of Clinton voters expressed surprise at the result, indicating that they had expected a different outcome [3][5]. This is further supported by the fact that Clinton voters were more likely to be pessimistic about Trump’s presidency, with 84% believing his election would worsen race relations [4].

The emotional divide is also evident in broader sentiments. Among all voters, 73% were surprised by Trump’s victory, with Clinton voters (87%) far more shocked than Trump voters (60%) [3][5]. ![Surprise levels among voters show Clinton supporters were most shocked](image2). This disparity underscores the extent to which Clinton voters underestimated Trump’s chances, while Trump supporters, though surprised, were more emotionally prepared for the possibility of a win.

In summary, Trump voters were predominantly happy but also surprised, while Clinton voters were overwhelmingly shocked and disappointed, reflecting their differing expectations of the election outcome and their contrasting views on the implications of Trump’s presidency.

After the 2016 election, voter sentiments toward Trump’s victory and expectations for a female president in their lifetime showed both similarities and differences between Trump and Clinton voters.  

A majority of Trump voters (97%) were happy about his victory, while 93% of Clinton voters expressed unhappiness [7]. This stark divide reflects the polarized reactions to the election outcome. Additionally, surprise was a shared sentiment, with 60% of Trump voters and 87% of Clinton voters expressing surprise at Trump’s win [5].  
![A bar chart showing surprise levels among voters, with 60% of Trump voters and 87% of Clinton voters expressing surprise](image1)  

Despite these differences in emotional reactions, expectations for a female president in their lifetime were remarkably similar across both groups. Around 79% of all voters, including 78% of Trump voters and 81% of Clinton voters, believed there would be a female president in their lifetime [1], as illustrated in the bar chart below.  
![A bar chart showing 79% of all voters expect a female president in their lifetime, with similar percentages among Trump and Clinton voters](image2)  

In summary, while Trump and Clinton voters differed significantly in their emotional reactions to Trump’s victory, they shared a similar optimism about the prospect of a female president in their lifetime.

Public perceptions of government efforts to combat terrorism have shifted significantly over time, with notable differences across political affiliations and age groups. Overall, confidence in the government’s ability to reduce the threat of terrorism has declined since the September 2001 attacks, reaching its lowest point in 2015. For the first time, more Americans (52%) now say the government is doing not too well or not at all well in this regard, compared to 46% who believe it is doing very or fairly well [2]. This marks a 26-point drop in positive ratings since January of the same year [2].

The perception of government efforts has become more negative across all political groups, but Democrats remain the only group where a majority (64%) still rates the government’s performance as at least fairly well, though this is down from 85% in January [3]. Independents’ positive ratings have dropped by 25 points, from 69% to 44%, while just 27% of Republicans now view the government’s efforts positively, a significant decline from 63% at the start of the year [3]. ![Political trends in government performance ratings](image1)

This trend is also reflected in concerns about anti-terrorism policies. A majority of Americans (56%) now worry that these policies have not gone far enough to protect the country, compared to 28% who believe they have gone too far in restricting civil liberties [10]. This represents a seven-point increase in concern about insufficient measures since the start of the year [10]. However, this sentiment varies by political affiliation. For instance, 71% of conservative Republicans and 67% of conservative and moderate Democrats share this concern, while liberal Democrats are evenly split (41% each) between fearing policies have gone too far and not far enough [1]. ![Shift in public opinion on anti-terrorism policies](image3)

Age groups also show distinct patterns in perceptions. Older Americans, particularly those aged 50 and above, are more critical of the government’s efforts, with 57% saying it is not doing well in reducing the terrorist threat [6]. In contrast, younger adults aged 18-29 are more positive, with 53% rating the government’s performance as very or fairly well [6]. Additionally, older and less educated individuals are more likely to give the government low marks compared to younger and more highly educated Americans [7][9]. ![Opinions on civil liberties versus national protection by age groups](image2)

In summary, public confidence in government efforts to combat terrorism has declined significantly, with Republicans and older adults being the most critical, while younger adults and Democrats remain somewhat more positive. Concerns about insufficient anti-terrorism measures have risen, reflecting a broader shift in public opinion. ![Demographic differences in government performance ratings](image5)

Perceptions of government efforts to reduce the terrorist threat vary significantly by age and political ideology, and these views have evolved over time.  

Younger adults (ages 18-29) are more likely to express concerns about government policies restricting civil liberties, with 43% believing policies have gone too far in this regard, compared to just 15% of those 65 and older [3]. ![Younger adults prioritize civil liberties over security](image2). In contrast, older adults (65+) are more concerned about the government not doing enough to protect the country, with 71% expressing this view, compared to 44% of younger adults [3].  

Political ideology also plays a key role. Democrats are more likely to view government efforts positively, with 64% saying the government is doing at least fairly well in reducing the terrorist threat, compared to just 27% of Republicans [7]. ![Democrats are more likely than Republicans to approve of government efforts](image3). Additionally, those with a postgraduate education are more likely to approve of government efforts (58%) compared to those with less education (44%) [9].  

Over time, there has been a noticeable shift in public opinion. Concern that government policies have gone too far in restricting civil liberties has decreased since 2013, dropping from 47% to 28%, while the belief that policies have not gone far enough to protect the country has risen from 35% to 56% [5]. ![Public opinion has shifted towards favoring stronger security measures over civil liberties](image5). This shift is also reflected in declining approval ratings of government efforts across all political affiliations, with Republicans showing the sharpest decline (from 63% positive in January 2015 to 27% later that year) [7]. Overall, age and political ideology continue to shape perceptions of government efforts to combat terrorism, with older adults and Democrats generally more supportive of current policies, while younger adults and Republicans express greater skepticism.

In 2015, perceptions of the government's performance in reducing the terrorist threat varied significantly across age groups. According to [4], a majority of those aged 50 and older (57%) believed the government was not doing well in reducing the terrorist threat, while 42% felt it was performing adequately. In contrast, younger adults (18-29 years old) were more divided, with 46% giving the government a negative rating and 53% saying it was doing very or fairly well. ![Age group perceptions on government performance in reducing terrorism](image4)

When it comes to views on whether anti-terror policies have gone too far in restricting civil liberties or not far enough to protect the country, there is a clear generational divide. As shown in [10], adults under 30 were almost evenly split, with 43% concerned about policies restricting civil liberties and 44% worried they didn’t go far enough to protect the country. In contrast, older age groups were more likely to prioritize security over civil liberties. For example, 71% of those aged 65 and older believed policies had not gone far enough, compared to 52% of those aged 30-49 [10]. ![Opinions on civil liberties vs. national protection by age group](image5)

Overall, older Americans were more critical of the government’s efforts to combat terrorism and more likely to support stronger anti-terror policies, while younger adults were more divided and concerned about the impact on civil liberties.

Over time, opinions on government anti-terrorism efforts have shifted significantly, with distinct patterns emerging across age groups and political affiliations. Younger adults (18-29) are nearly split between concerns that anti-terrorism policies place too many restrictions on civil liberties (43%) and that they do not go far enough to protect the country (44%) [8]. In contrast, older age groups show a stronger preference for security over civil liberties, with 71% of those aged 65 and older expressing concern that policies do not go far enough, compared to 52% of those aged 30-49 [8]. 

![Opinion distribution across age groups on anti-terrorism policies](image4)

Across political affiliations, Republicans are more likely to say that anti-terrorism policies have not gone far enough, with 71% expressing this view, up from 38% in 2013 [4]. Democrats also show an increase in this concern, with 54% now stating that policies do not go far enough, a 16-point rise since 2013 [3]. However, liberal Democrats are evenly split, with 41% concerned about policies restricting civil liberties and 41% worried they do not go far enough [7]. Independents fall between these extremes, with 49% expressing concern that policies do not go far enough [3].

![Public opinion trends on anti-terrorism policies from 2004 to 2015](image2)

Overall, there has been a notable shift in public opinion since 2013, particularly after Edward Snowden’s disclosures about NSA surveillance programs, with a growing emphasis on security over civil liberties. This trend is more pronounced among Republicans and older age groups, while younger adults and liberal Democrats remain more divided. ![Opinion trends across political affiliations from 2004 to 2015](image3)

Public perceptions of the U.S. military campaign against ISIS, and its potential success, have shown both consistency and shifts over time, with notable differences across political affiliations. 

![Bar chart showing the percentage of Republicans, Democrats, and Independents who perceive various issues as major threats to the well-being of the U.S.](image1) The perceived threat of ISIS is high across all political groups, with Republicans (93%) expressing the most concern, followed by Democrats and Independents (both at 79%). This suggests that while the threat is universally acknowledged, Republicans are significantly more alarmed.

![Line graph showing approval and disapproval ratings of the U.S. military campaign over time](image2) Approval of the U.S. military campaign has remained steady, with 64% approving in December 2015, up from 54% in August 2014. Disapproval ratings have also remained relatively stable, with a slight decline from 31% to 28% over the same period. This indicates sustained public support for the campaign despite mixed assessments of its effectiveness.

![Bar chart showing opinions on whether a policy will go far enough to stop militants across different groups](image3) Opinions on whether the U.S. will go far enough in stopping militants vary by political affiliation. Notably, 75% of Republicans are concerned that the U.S. will not go far enough, compared to 67% of Liberal Democrats. This partisan divide highlights differing expectations and priorities in addressing the ISIS threat.

![Bar chart comparing perceptions of the campaign's effectiveness over time, categorized as "Not too/at all well" versus "Very/Fairly well"](image4) Assessments of how well the campaign is going have remained largely negative, with 58% in December 2015 saying it is going "Not too/at all well." This view has been consistent since October 2014, indicating a persistent skepticism about the campaign's current efficacy.

![Bar chart comparing optimism about the campaign's potential success between July and December 2015](image5) Despite these negative assessments, optimism about the campaign's ultimate success has grown. In July 2015, 55% believed the U.S. and its allies would succeed; by December 2015, this figure rose to 66%. This increase suggests that while the public remains critical of the campaign's current state, there is growing confidence in its eventual success.

Across political affiliations, Republicans, Democrats, and Independents all express majority confidence in the campaign's ultimate success (65%, 72%, and 62%, respectively) [2]. However, there are wider partisan divides in current assessments of the campaign's effectiveness, with only 26% of Republicans viewing it positively compared to 45% of Democrats [2]. 

In summary, public perceptions of the U.S. military campaign against ISIS have shown steady approval rates and growing optimism about its success, despite persistent skepticism about its current effectiveness. These views vary significantly across political affiliations, with Republicans expressing the most concern about the threat of ISIS and the campaign's adequacy, while Democrats are more optimistic about its progress.

Perceptions of Islam’s encouragement of violence have varied significantly among different political affiliations, with a growing partisan divide. Republicans are far more likely to associate Islam with violence, with 68% saying it is more likely to encourage violence than other religions, a historical high but largely unchanged since 2014 [5][9]. In contrast, only 30% of Democrats hold this view, a 12-point decline since 2014 [5][9]. Independents fall in between, with 46% saying Islam is more likely to encourage violence and 45% saying it is not [3][10].

These perceptions align with wider partisan trends. ![The partisan divide over Islam and violence has grown significantly since 2002.](image4) The graph shows that the gap between Republicans and Democrats on this issue has widened over time, reflecting deeper polarization [7][9].

Views on government handling of terrorism also correlate with these perceptions. ![Perceptions of government performance on terrorism have grown more negative across the political spectrum.](image3) Since 2015, confidence in the government’s ability to combat terrorism has dropped sharply, particularly among Republicans, with only 27% saying the government is doing very or fairly well, down from 63% [6]. Democrats, despite their lower association of Islam with violence, have also seen a decline in confidence, with 64% now saying the government is doing at least fairly well, compared to 85% in early 2015 [6].

Overall, the widening partisan gap in perceptions of Islam and violence is mirrored by increasing skepticism about the government’s effectiveness in addressing terrorism. ![Republicans are more likely than Democrats to associate Islam with violence and to criticize government handling of terrorism.](image5) Republicans are more critical of the government’s performance and more likely to view Islam as encouraging violence, while Democrats show lower levels of both concerns but have still lost confidence in government efforts [6][9].

Perceptions of Islam encouraging violence have shifted over time among different political affiliations, with notable partisan divides. Republicans are more likely to associate Islam with violence, with $68\%$ holding this view in 2015, a historical high but little changed since 2014 [3]. In contrast, only $30\%$ of Democrats share this view, down from $42\%$ in 2014 [8]. Independents remain split, with $45\%$ saying Islam encourages violence more than other religions [9]. ![Republican, Democrat, and Independent views on Islam and violence have diverged significantly over time](image1)

Public opinions on party capabilities in handling terrorism also reveal partisan differences. The Republican Party is perceived as more capable, with $46\%$ of the public favoring it compared to $34\%$ for the Democratic Party [6]. This aligns with the trend of Republicans being more likely to associate Islam with violence, while Democrats have moved away from this perception. ![The Republican Party is perceived as stronger on handling terrorism than the Democratic Party](image3)

Over time, the gap between Republicans and Democrats on this issue has widened. Conservative Republicans overwhelmingly believe Islam encourages violence more than other religions ($77\%$), while $73\%$ of liberal Democrats disagree [7]. This ideological divide reflects broader trends in political polarization. ![Public perceptions of Islam and violence have become increasingly polarized along political lines](image5) Overall, while Republicans have maintained or increased their association of Islam with violence, Democrats have moved away from this view, and the public remains divided on both this issue and party capabilities in handling terrorism.

Perceptions of scrutiny of Muslims in the U.S. vary significantly across political and demographic groups, and these views are often tied to the perceived importance of terrorism as a national issue.

Starting with political affiliations, Conservative Republicans are the only group where a majority (57%) supports greater scrutiny of Muslims due to their religion [3]. In contrast, 87% of Liberal Democrats oppose such scrutiny, reflecting a stark ideological divide [2]. Republicans overall are nearly evenly split (49% for, 44% against), while clear majorities of independents (62%) and Democrats (76%) oppose additional scrutiny [5]. ![Political group breakdown on religious scrutiny](image3)

Age also plays a role in these perceptions. Young adults (18-29) overwhelmingly reject scrutinizing Muslims (80%), as do 63% of those aged 30-49. However, views are more divided among those 50 and older, with 50% supporting additional scrutiny [1][8]. ![Demographic perspectives on religious scrutiny](image2)

Racial and ethnic differences are evident as well. Non-whites are more likely to oppose scrutiny based on religion, with 74% of Blacks and 66% of Hispanics rejecting it, compared to 57% of Whites [10].

These perceptions align with the varying importance placed on terrorism as a national issue. Republicans are far more likely to prioritize terrorism, defense, and national security (41%) compared to independents (28%) and Democrats (23%) [4]. This focus may explain the higher support among Republicans for scrutinizing Muslims, as they view terrorism as a more pressing concern. ![Political priorities regarding national issues](image4)

Additionally, the increasing concern about terrorism over time, with mentions rising from 1% in 2014 to 18% in 2015, may have further polarized views on Muslim scrutiny [5]. ![Changes in public concerns over time](image5)

In summary, Conservative Republicans and older adults are more likely to support scrutinizing Muslims, while Liberal Democrats, younger adults, and non-whites oppose it. These differences correlate with the varying importance placed on terrorism as a national issue, with Republicans prioritizing it more highly than other groups.

Perceptions of terrorism and government efforts to combat terrorism have shifted significantly over time, with notable differences among demographic and political groups.

![](image1)
Public concern about terrorism surged between December 2014 and December 2015, with mentions increasing from 1% to 18% (+17). Similarly, concerns about defense/national security and ISIS rose by 6% and 5%, respectively. This reflects a broader trend, with foreign and international issues gaining prominence (+23%) while economic concerns declined (-11%) [7][1].

![](image4)
Evaluations of government efforts to combat terrorism have grown more negative. Overall, 52% now say the government is doing "not too well" or "not at all well" in reducing the threat, compared to 46% who rate it positively. This marks the lowest approval since 2001 [3]. Older adults (50+) are more critical, with 57% giving negative ratings, while younger adults (18-29) are more positive (53%) [2]. Those with postgraduate education are also more likely to approve (58%) compared to those with less education [6].

![](image3)
Political affiliation plays a significant role in these perceptions. Republicans are more likely to prioritize terrorism and national security (41%) compared to Democrats (23%) and Independents (28%) [1]. However, positive ratings of government efforts have declined across all groups. Among Democrats, approval dropped from 85% to 64%, while Republicans’ positive ratings fell from 63% to 27% [4].

![](image5)
Concerns about government anti-terror policies have also shifted. A majority (56%) now feel these policies have "not gone far enough," a 7-point increase from earlier in the year. This sentiment is stronger among older and less educated Americans, who are more critical of government efforts [9][10].

In summary, perceptions of terrorism as a critical issue have intensified, particularly among Republicans and older Americans, while approval of government efforts to combat it has declined across all demographic and political groups.

According to the survey results, there are significant differences in how Republicans and Democrats view terrorism and economic issues. 

Republicans are more likely to prioritize terrorism and defense issues, with 41% mentioning these as top concerns, compared to only 23% of Democrats [5]. This trend is also evident in the aggregated data, where Republicans show higher prioritization for categories like "Terrorism/ISIS/National security" in the survey table ![Republicans prioritize terrorism more than Democrats](image1). Additionally, Republicans are more concerned that anti-terrorism policies do not go far enough, with 71% expressing this view compared to a more balanced perspective among liberal Democrats [2].

On the other hand, Democrats are less focused on terrorism and more likely to cite economic issues. While the table shows that both parties prioritize economic issues to some extent, Democrats generally place greater emphasis on concerns like dissatisfaction with government and political gridlock (8% of Democrats vs. 2% of Republicans) [7]. ![Democrats prioritize economic issues and political gridlock more](image1).

The shift in priorities is also reflected in the broader categories, where "Economic issues" saw a net decrease in focus over time, particularly among Democrats ![Economic issues declined in focus while terrorism increased](image4). These differences underscore the stark partisan divides in how Republicans and Democrats perceive the nation’s most pressing problems.

Views on the importance of terrorism vary significantly among political affiliations. Republicans are far more likely to prioritize terrorism, with 41% mentioning it as a critical issue, compared to 28% of independents and 23% of Democrats [6]. This contrasts with Democrats, who are more likely to cite partisan gridlock and division as the most important problem facing the nation [2].

![Political affiliations differ in priority of terrorism, with Republicans emphasizing it more](image3)

These differing priorities are reflected in their perceptions of government efforts to address the terrorist threat. Republicans are much more critical of the government’s performance, with only 27% saying it is doing very or fairly well, a significant drop from 63% at the beginning of the year [4]. In contrast, Democrats, while still critical, are the only group where a majority (64%) believe the government is doing at least fairly well, though this is down from 85% earlier in the year [4]. Independents’ positive ratings have also declined sharply, from 69% to 44% [4].

![Perceptions of government efforts to reduce terrorism vary by political affiliation](image2)

Overall, the prioritization of terrorism as an issue aligns with greater dissatisfaction with government efforts among Republicans, while Democrats, who focus less on terrorism, are relatively more supportive of the government’s actions. This divergence highlights the partisan nature of both issue prioritization and government performance evaluations.

Independent voters' views on government regulation and economic fairness differ significantly from those of Democrats and Republicans. On the issue of government regulation, independents are divided: 48% believe regulation is necessary to protect the public interest, while 43% think it does more harm than good [1]. This contrasts with Democrats, who overwhelmingly support regulation (65% say it is necessary), and Republicans, who lean against it (61% say it does more harm) [1].

![Independent voters are split on the necessity of government regulation, with 48% supporting it and 43% opposing it.](image1)

Regarding economic fairness, 66% of independents believe the U.S. economic system unfairly favors powerful interests, while only 30% think it is generally fair to most Americans [4]. This aligns more closely with Democrats, 85% of whom share the view that the system favors powerful interests, but contrasts sharply with Republicans, among whom 63% believe the system is fair [4].

![Most independents (66%) believe the U.S. economic system unfairly favors powerful interests, aligning closer to Democrats than Republicans.](image4)

Overall, independents occupy a middle ground between the more polarized positions of Democrats and Republicans on these issues. Their views on government regulation are split, while their skepticism about economic fairness aligns more with Democrats than Republicans.
