Over the past two decades, unfavorable views toward both major U.S. political parties have shifted significantly among independents. In 1994, only 6% of independents held unfavorable views of both parties, but this number rose to 12% by 2018 [1]. This trend is illustrated in the line graph, which shows a steady increase in this sentiment over time among independents ![Rise in unfavorable views of both parties among independents](image1). 

Among subgroups of independents, those who do not lean toward either party are most likely to have unfavorable opinions of both parties, with 37% holding this view in recent years [2]. In contrast, only 22% of this group have favorable opinions of both parties. For independents who lean toward a party, the data shows a strong partisan imprint, with majorities favoring their own party and viewing the opposing party negatively. For example, 55% of Republican-leaning independents and 56% of Democratic-leaning independents hold unfavorable views of the opposing party, nearly matching the levels of negative sentiment among partisan identifiers [10].

The intensity of these unfavorable views has also grown. For instance, the share of Democratic-leaning independents with a "very unfavorable" opinion of the Republican Party quadrupled from 8% in 1994 to 37% in 2018, while Republican-leaning independents saw a similar increase in very unfavorable views of the Democratic Party, rising from 15% to 39% over the same period [6]. This polarization is further highlighted in the line graph showing increasing unfavorable views of the opposing party among independents over time ![Polarization in unfavorable views among independents](image4). 

In summary, unfavorable views of both major parties have increased among independents over time, with the highest levels found among those who do not lean toward either party, while partisan-leaning independents exhibit strong negative views of the opposing party.

Over the past two decades, unfavorable views toward the opposing party have surged across all political affiliations. Among Democrats, the percentage with a very unfavorable view of the Republican Party rose from 59% in 1994 to 88% in 2018 [8]. Similarly, Republican-leaning independents saw their very unfavorable opinions of the Democratic Party increase from 64% in 1994 to 81% in 2018 [4]. This trend is mirrored among Republican partisans, whose very unfavorable views of the Democratic Party grew from 77% in 1994 to 87% in 2018 [8]. ![The line graph shows rising unfavorable views of the opposing party among Democrats, Republicans, and independents from 1994 to 2018.](image4)

Independents, particularly those who do not lean toward a party, are most likely to view both parties unfavorably. As of 2018, 37% of non-leaning independents held unfavorable opinions of both the Republican and Democratic parties [6]. This contrasts with the 22% of non-leaning independents who have favorable opinions of both parties. Additionally, only 11% of non-leaning independents view the Democratic Party favorably, while 9% have a favorable view of the GOP [6]. ![The bar chart illustrates the percentage of non-leaning independents with unfavorable views of both parties.](image1)

In summary, unfavorable views of the opposing party have grown significantly over time across all political groups, with non-leaning independents most likely to hold negative opinions of both parties.

Republicans and Democrats differ significantly in their perceptions of China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak and its impact on U.S.-China relations. Republicans are far more critical of China's response to the pandemic, with **82% stating that China did a bad job**, and **61% saying it was a very bad job**. In contrast, **54% of Democrats** believe China handled the outbreak poorly, with only **30% viewing it as very bad** [10]. This disparity is also evident in age groups, as older Americans, particularly those 50 and older, are more critical of China's actions [10].

![Republicans and Democrats differ in their views of China's handling of the pandemic, with 82% of Republicans seeing it as bad compared to 54% of Democrats.](image1)

Republicans are also more likely to blame China for the global spread of the virus, with **73% believing China’s early handling contributed a great deal**, compared to **38% of Democrats** [5]. This sentiment is reflected in their policy preferences, as **71% of Republicans** think the U.S. should hold China responsible even if it worsens economic relations, while only **37% of Democrats** agree [9].

![The majority of Republicans (73%) believe China's initial handling of the outbreak contributed a great deal to the global spread, compared to 38% of Democrats.](image4)

Over time, Republicans' negative views of China have grown more pronounced. From 2005 to 2020, **Republicans/Lean Republicans** saw their negative perception increase from 39% to 83%, while **Democrats/Lean Democrats** rose from 34% to 68% [3].

![Republicans' negative views of China have increased sharply from 39% in 2005 to 83% in 2020, outpacing Democrats' rise from 34% to 68%.](image3)

In summary, Republicans are significantly more critical of China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak and more inclined to hold China accountable, even at the expense of U.S.-China relations, compared to Democrats.

Republicans are significantly more critical of China’s handling of COVID-19 compared to Democrats. According to the survey, **82% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents** believe China has done a bad job dealing with the coronavirus, while only **54% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents** share this view. Additionally, Republicans are about twice as likely to say China has done a **very bad job** (61% vs. 30%) [10]. 

Older Americans, particularly those aged 50 and older, also tend to be more critical, with **73%** finding fault in China’s response [7]. This aligns with the broader trend that **73% of Republicans** believe China’s early handling of the pandemic contributed a great deal to its global spread, compared to **38% of Democrats** who say the same [7].

Over time, perceptions of China’s role in the pandemic and its handling of the crisis have become more negative across both political groups. The line graph shows that **Republicans/Lean Rep** and **Democrats/Lean Dem** have both experienced significant increases in negative views of China from 2005 to 2020, with Republicans peaking at **83%** and Democrats at **68%** in 2020 ![Trends in negative views of China have increased for both Republicans and Democrats over time](image2). 

Furthermore, the perception of U.S.-China economic ties has worsened, with **63% of Republicans** and **73% of Democrats** now believing bilateral economic relations are bad, marking increases of **15** and **12** percentage points, respectively, from 2019 [4]. ![Negative views of U.S.-China economic ties have increased across political groups](image3).

In summary, Republicans are more critical of China’s handling of COVID-19 than Democrats, and these negative perceptions have grown significantly over time across both political groups.

Americans generally hold critical views of China’s role in the coronavirus outbreak and its handling of the pandemic. Around two-thirds (64%) of Americans believe China has done a bad job managing the crisis, including 43% who say it has done a very bad job [10]. This perception is linked to the belief that China’s initial handling of the outbreak significantly contributed to the global spread of the virus. Three-quarters of Americans say China’s actions in Wuhan contributed either a great deal (51%) or a fair amount (27%) to the pandemic’s worldwide impact [4].

![A majority of Americans believe China contributed greatly to the virus spread](image2)

Political affiliations significantly shape these views. Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are far more critical of China than Democrats, with 82% of Republicans saying China has done a bad job compared to 54% of Democrats [8]. Similarly, 73% of Republicans believe China’s early handling contributed a great deal to the virus’s spread, while only 38% of Democrats agree [4]. This partisan divide extends to opinions on how the U.S. should respond. A majority of Republicans (71%) think the U.S. should hold China responsible even if it worsens economic relations, compared to 37% of Democrats [7].

![Republicans are more critical of China than Democrats](image3)

Older Americans are also more likely to blame China for the pandemic, with 73% of those aged 50 and older finding fault in China’s handling of the crisis [8]. Additionally, half of Americans believe the U.S. should prioritize holding China accountable over maintaining strong economic ties [5]. This sentiment is reflected in the broader trend of shifting U.S. attitudes toward China. While public opinion has fluctuated over the past decade, there has been a recent increase in those favoring a tougher stance, rising from 35% in 2018 to 46% in 2020 [4].

![U.S. public opinion on China has shifted toward a tougher stance over time](image4)

In summary, Americans are highly critical of China’s role in the coronavirus outbreak, with Republicans and older adults being particularly harsh in their assessments. These views have led to a growing preference for holding China accountable, even at the expense of economic relations.

American perceptions of China's role in handling COVID-19 and broader U.S.-China relations have become increasingly negative, with a strong emphasis on blame and strained economic ties.  

A significant majority of Americans, 64%, believe China has done a **bad job** in dealing with the coronavirus outbreak [7]. This sentiment is further reinforced by the fact that 78% of Americans place **a great deal or fair amount of blame** on the Chinese government for the global spread of COVID-19, particularly due to its initial handling of the outbreak in Wuhan [7]. ![78% of Americans blame China for the global spread of COVID-19](image5).

This blame has contributed to souring views of China more broadly. **73% of U.S. adults** now hold an unfavorable view of the country, a sharp increase of **26 percentage points since 2018** [5]. This trend is evident across all age groups and political affiliations, though Republicans and older Americans are more likely to hold negative views [2]. ![73% of Americans have an unfavorable view of China](image2).

Economic relations between the U.S. and China are also seen as **in bad shape**, with 68% of Americans describing them this way, a 15-point increase since May 2019 [8]. While **51% of Americans** prefer pursuing a strong economic relationship with China, nearly half (46%) support getting tough on the country economically [2]. However, those who view the U.S. as economically dominant are less likely to prioritize punitive measures and more inclined to focus on strengthening economic ties [3]. ![Republicans show stronger negative sentiments towards China across various issues](image1).

When it comes to holding China accountable for its role in the pandemic, **50% of Americans** believe the U.S. should do so even if it worsens economic relations, while 38% think strong bilateral ties should take precedence [2]. This divide is especially pronounced along political lines, with **71% of Republicans** supporting holding China responsible compared to 37% of Democrats [10].

In summary, American perceptions of China have deteriorated significantly, with widespread blame for its handling of COVID-19 and growing support for a tougher stance on economic and political issues, even at the risk of damaging bilateral relations. ![Unfavorable views of China have risen sharply since 2005](image4).

Negative perceptions of China have significantly increased over time across all age groups and political affiliations, with older Americans and Republicans expressing the most unfavorable views. ![Negative perceptions of China increase with age, with 81% of those 50+ holding unfavorable views](image4) Older Americans, particularly those aged 50 and above, have seen a sharp rise in negative views, with 81% now holding unfavorable opinions, up 10 percentage points since March [3]. This trend is consistent across education levels and gender, with around seven-in-ten Americans maintaining negative views regardless of these factors [4].

Similarly, political affiliation plays a significant role in shaping perceptions. Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more likely to hold unfavorable views of China (83%) compared to Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents (68%) [6]. This partisan divide has widened over time, as Republicans are also more likely to express *very* unfavorable views (54%) compared to Democrats (35%) [6]. ![Republicans consistently hold more unfavorable views of China than Democrats, with a widening gap over time](image5)

A long-term perspective reveals that negative perceptions have steadily grown across age groups. From 2005 to 2020, unfavorable views among those aged 18-29 increased from 26% to 56%, while those aged 30-49 rose from 41% to 71%. The most dramatic increase was among those aged 50 and older, climbing from 34% to 81% [image3]. ![Unfavorable views of China have risen across all age groups from 2005 to 2020, with the sharpest increase among those aged 50+](image3)

In summary, negative perceptions of China have surged across all demographics, with older Americans and Republicans exhibiting the highest levels of disapproval.

Unfavorable views of China have increased significantly over time among all age groups and political affiliations in the United States. ![The line graph shows unfavorable views among Republicans peaking at 83% and Democrats at 68% in 2020](image1) Republicans have consistently held more negative views, with 83% expressing unfavorable opinions compared to 68% of Democrats in 2020 [7]. Over the past four months alone, negative views among Republicans increased by 11 percentage points, while Democrats saw a 6-point increase, widening the partisan gap to 15 points [3]. ![The bar chart shows rising unfavorable views across age groups, with 81% of those aged 50+ holding negative opinions](image2) Older Americans (50+) are the most critical, with 81% holding unfavorable views, a 10-point increase since March. This contrasts with 71% of those aged 30-49 and 56% of those under 30 [9]. ![The line graph illustrates a steady rise in unfavorable views across all age groups from 2005 to 2020](image4) Overall, 73% of Americans now have an unfavorable view of China, the highest in 15 years, with very unfavorable views doubling since 2019 to 42% [2][6]. These trends highlight deepening skepticism across demographics.

Views on China vary significantly across age groups and political affiliations, and these perceptions have evolved over time. 

![Older adults and Republicans hold the most unfavorable views of China.](image3) For the total population, 73% have an unfavorable view of China, with 22% holding favorable views. This sentiment is even stronger among older adults (ages 50+), where 81% view China unfavorably, compared to 71% of those aged 30-49 and 56% of those under 30 [6]. Politically, Republicans overwhelmingly hold negative views, with 83% viewing China unfavorably, while 68% of Democrats share this sentiment [1]. 

![Negative perceptions of China have increased steadily across all age groups since 2005.](image4) Younger adults (18-29) have seen their unfavorable views rise from 26% in 2005 to 56% in 2020, while those aged 30-49 increased from 41% to 67%, and the 50+ group surged from 34% to 81% [6].

![Republicans' negative views of China have consistently outpaced those of Democrats over the past 15 years.](image2) Republicans’ unfavorable views have risen sharply from 39% in 2005 to 83% in 2020, while Democrats’ negative perceptions increased from 34% to 68% over the same period [2][9]. This trend has widened the gap between the two parties.

In summary, older adults and Republicans consistently hold the most negative views of China, and these perceptions have grown stronger over the years across all demographics.

Negative opinions of China in the United States have increased significantly over time across all age groups and political affiliations, though the degree of change varies. ![Line graph showing upward trends in negative opinions among age groups from 2005 to 2020](image3) The data reveals that among those aged 18-29, unfavorable views rose from 26% in 2005 to 56% in 2020. For the 30-49 age group, negative opinions increased from 41% to 71%, and for those aged 50 and older, the rise was even more pronounced, from 34% to 81% [3][5][7]. Older Americans, particularly those over 50, have consistently held the most negative views, with their disapproval increasing by 10 percentage points in recent months alone [5].

Politically, Republicans and Republican-leaning independents have always been more critical of China compared to Democrats and Democratic leaners. ![Line graph showing increasing unfavorable views among Republicans and Democrats from 2005 to 2020](image5) In 2020, 83% of Republicans held unfavorable views, compared to 68% of Democrats [6][9]. Over the past 15 years, Republican disapproval rose from 39% to 83%, while Democratic disapproval increased from 34% to 68% [6][9]. Republicans are also more likely to hold very unfavorable views (54%) than Democrats (35%) [6]. Overall, 73% of Americans now have an unfavorable opinion of China, marking the highest level in the 15 years Pew Research Center has tracked these views [8].

These trends reflect a broader consensus across demographics, with older Americans and Republicans leading the shift toward more negative perceptions of China. ![Bar chart showing unfavorable views of China across age groups and political affiliations](image2) The data highlights how both age and political ideology shape attitudes, with older individuals and Republicans expressing the most criticism.

Americans' perception of China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic varies significantly across age groups and political affiliations. Overall, 64% of Americans believe China has done a bad job managing the outbreak, with 43% describing it as a very bad job [3]. Older Americans, particularly those aged 50 and older, are more critical, with 73% finding fault in China’s response, compared to 59% of those aged 30-49 and 54% of those under 30 [9]. ![Older Americans are more critical of China's pandemic response](image3).

Politically, Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more likely to view China’s handling negatively, with 82% saying it has done a bad job compared to 54% of Democrats and Democratic leaners. Additionally, 61% of Republicans believe China has done a *very* bad job, versus 30% of Democrats [9]. ![Republicans are significantly more critical than Democrats](image5).

Interestingly, these critical views align with broader unfavorable opinions of China, which have increased over time. Since 2005, unfavorable views among Republicans have risen from 39% to 83%, and among Democrats from 34% to 68% [5]. ![Unfavorable views of China have increased significantly over time](image1). Similarly, older Americans (50+) hold more negative views (81%) compared to younger age groups (56% for under 30 and 71% for 30-49) [7], a trend also reflected in perceptions of China’s pandemic response. ![Older age groups hold more unfavorable views of China](image2).

Overall, both political affiliation and age significantly influence perceptions of China’s COVID-19 handling, mirroring broader trends in unfavorable views toward the country.

Perceptions of China’s handling of COVID-19 vary significantly across age groups and political affiliations. Older Americans and Republicans are notably more critical of China’s response compared to younger individuals and Democrats.

For age groups, 73% of those aged 50 and older say China has done a bad job in its pandemic response, compared to 59% of those aged 30-49 and 54% of those under 30 [1]. This trend is further supported by the data showing that older individuals are more likely to blame China’s early handling of the outbreak for the global spread of the virus [3]. ![Unfavorable views of China increase with age](image2)

Politically, Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are significantly more critical, with 82% saying China has done a bad job, compared to 54% of Democrats and Democratic leaners. Additionally, 61% of Republicans believe China has done a very bad job, versus 30% of Democrats [1]. Republicans are also more likely—73%—to say China’s early handling contributed a great deal to the global spread of the virus, compared to 38% of Democrats [3]. ![Republicans have higher unfavorable views of China than Democrats](image3)

The broader trend of increasing negative views toward China is also evident, with Republicans seeing an 11-point increase in unfavorable views over four months, while Democrats saw a 6-point increase, resulting in a 15-point gap between the parties [10]. ![Negative views of China have risen among both Republicans and Democrats](image3)

Overall, older individuals and Republicans hold more critical views of China’s handling of COVID-19 compared to younger individuals and Democrats.

Political affiliations in the U.S. and Germany significantly shape preferences for foreign policy partners and desired cooperation levels. In the U.S., Democrats and Republicans both rank the UK as their most important foreign policy partner, but Republicans show a stronger preference for Israel (26%) compared to Democrats (9%). Democrats also place more emphasis on Canada and Mexico, while views of Germany are similar across both parties, with both ranking it fifth on their list of most important partners [8].  

![Political alignment and preferences for foreign policy partners](image5)  

When it comes to cooperation, Democrats are more likely than Republicans to favor closer ties with Germany (66% vs. 57%) and less likely to prefer close relations with Russia (21% vs. 31%) [4]. Republicans are also more inclined to support increased cooperation with Russia (41%) compared to Democrats (32%) [5].  

In Germany, supporters of the CDU/CSU are more willing to cooperate with the U.S. than those backing the Greens or SPD. This aligns with the international image of the U.S. among Germans, where those on the ideological right tend to view the U.S. more favorably [3]. Germans overall are more supportive of closer ties with Russia, especially those in former East Germany (75%), compared to their counterparts in the West (63%) [5].  

![Comparison of foreign policy preferences by political affiliation in the U.S.](image4)  

![Comparative chart of preferences for cooperation between Germany and Russia](image3)  

These partisan differences are also reflected in desired influence levels. Americans generally want more cooperation with European allies like the UK (76%), France (71%), and Germany (69%) [1], while Germans are less enthusiastic about increased cooperation with the U.S. (50%) [2]. However, the percentage of Germans wanting to cooperate more with the U.S. has risen by nine points since 2018 [2].  

![Comparative chart of influence preferences in the U.S. and Germany](image2)  

Overall, political affiliations in both countries not only influence which nations are favored as foreign policy partners but also shape the extent of desired cooperation, reflecting broader ideological and historical contexts.

Americans and Germans differ significantly in their preferences for increased cooperation with Russia and China. Germans are almost twice as likely as Americans to want greater collaboration with Russia, with 75% of East Germans and 63% of West Germans supporting increased cooperation, compared to 41% of Republicans and 32% of Democrats in the U.S. [3]. This preference is also reflected in the broader German population, where 66% support more cooperation with Russia, while only 35% of Americans share this view ![Less support for Russia in the U.S. than in Germany](image1).

In terms of political party affiliations in the U.S., Republicans are more inclined toward increased cooperation with Russia (41%) compared to Democrats (32%) [3]. Conversely, Democrats show stronger support for closer ties with Germany (66%) than Republicans (57%) [2]. This aligns with the broader partisan divide, where Democrats are more favorable toward Germany, while Republicans lean slightly more toward Russia [9].

When it comes to China, younger Americans (18-29) are more likely to prioritize a close relationship with China (58%) over Germany (32%), while older Americans prioritize Germany [4]. Germans, however, are twice as likely to prefer a close relationship with the U.S. over China (50% to 24%) [10]. This divergence is also evident in cooperation preferences, where similar majorities in both countries support cooperation with China, though Americans are slightly more divided [7].

In Germany, partisan differences also play a role. Supporters of the CDU/CSU are more willing to cooperate with the U.S. than those supporting the Greens or SPD [9]. This is consistent with the broader trend where ideological right-leaning Germans tend to view the U.S. more favorably [9]. ![Partisan differences in cooperation preferences in the U.S. and Germany](image3).

Overall, while both Americans and Germans show some support for cooperation with Russia and China, the levels and partisan influences differ significantly, with Germans favoring Russia more strongly and Americans showing a mixed but partisan-influenced stance.

In the U.S., political party affiliation significantly shapes attitudes towards cooperation with Russia and China. Republicans and Democrats differ markedly in their preferences: 31% of Republicans favor close relations with Russia, compared to only 21% of Democrats [5]. Conversely, Democrats are more likely to prioritize cooperation with Germany (66%) than Republicans (57%) [5]. 

![Chart showing party alignment percentages in the U.S. and Germany](image1)

This partisan divide is also evident in attitudes towards China. While Americans overall lean slightly towards China (44%) over Germany (41%), younger Americans (58%) are notably more inclined towards China than older generations [6]. Additionally, Republicans are more likely to support Israel as a key foreign policy partner (26%) compared to Democrats (9%) [4]. 

In Germany, the political landscape shows similar patterns but with less polarization. Supporters of CDU/CSU are more favorable towards the U.S. than those aligned with the Greens and SPD [1]. Germans in the former East are more supportive of closer ties with Russia (75%) than those in the former West (63%) [3]. 

![](image4)

When comparing preferences between the U.S. and Germany, Americans clearly favor Germany over Russia (61% to 26%), while Germans show a narrower preference for the U.S. over Russia (39% to 25%) [5]. 

These insights highlight how political party preferences shape attitudes towards international cooperation, with U.S. partisanship creating sharper divides than in Germany.

In the U.S., there is a noticeable partisan divide regarding cooperation with Russia. Republicans are more likely to favor increased collaboration with Russia (41%) compared to Democrats (32%)[2]. This preference is also reflected in the choice of close relationships, with 31% of Republicans preferring ties with Russia, while only 21% of Democrats share this view[4]. ![Republicans in the U.S. are more inclined toward cooperation with Russia than Democrats.](image1)

In Germany, the regional and ideological differences play a significant role. Germans living in former East Germany are far more supportive of closer ties with Russia (75%) compared to those in former West Germany (63%)[2]. This regional divide is further emphasized by the fact that nearly four-in-ten East Germans prefer a close relationship with Russia, while West Germans are twice as likely to favor the U.S. over Russia[7]. ![East Germans prioritize relations with Russia over the U.S.](image3)

Additionally, conservative Americans and Germans on the ideological right are more likely to view Russia favorably than their liberal counterparts[9]. This ideological divide is more pronounced among Americans, with conservatives being more inclined toward Russia, while liberals tend to favor international organizations like the UN and EU. ![Conservatives in both the U.S. and Germany are more likely to view Russia favorably.](image1)

Overall, political affiliations in both the U.S. and Germany significantly shape attitudes toward cooperation with Russia, with Republicans and East Germans showing stronger preferences for closer ties.

Americans and Germans have distinct perspectives on the world’s leading economic power and their international relationships with entities like the EU and China. When asked which country they consider the top economic power, **half of Americans name the U.S.**, while about a third (32%) choose China. In contrast, **53% of Germans name China**, with only 24% selecting the U.S. This stark difference in perception is visualized in the bar chart, which shows the U.S. at 50% for Americans and 24% for Germans, and China at 32% for Americans and 53% for Germans. ![Views on the leading economic power vary significantly between Americans and Germans.](image4)

Regarding international relationships, Germans tend to view the EU more favorably than Americans. **Roughly seven-in-ten Germans favor the EU**, compared to only **about half of Americans**. This divide is reflected in the comparative chart, where Germany shows a 69% approval rating for the EU, while the U.S. lags at 51%. ![Germans hold a more positive view of the EU compared to Americans.](image5)

Similarly, there is a notable gap in perceptions of China. Despite both countries viewing China less favorably than the EU, **Germans (41%) have a more positive opinion of China than Americans (26%)**—a difference of 15 percentage points. ![Germans express a slightly higher approval of China than Americans.](image5)

These differences extend to cooperation preferences. **Nearly 70% of Americans want to cooperate more with Germany**, while only **half of Germans say the same about the U.S.** However, the percentage of Germans wanting to cooperate with the U.S. has increased by nine points since 2018 [3].

In summary, Americans and Germans diverge sharply in their views on the leading economic power, with Americans favoring the U.S. and Germans favoring China, and Germans consistently hold more favorable views of international entities like the EU and China compared to Americans.

Americans and Germans exhibit notable differences in their views of international organizations and economic powers, shaped by political ideology, regional history, and national perspectives. 

Starting with international organizations, Germans generally hold more favorable views of entities like the EU, UN, and NATO compared to Americans. For instance, 69% of Germans favor the EU, while only 51% of Americans do, marking an 18% difference [1][image1]. Similarly, Germans have a 65% approval rating for the UN, compared to 59% for Americans, and 57% for NATO versus 52% for Americans [1][image1]. These differences are partly influenced by political ideology. In the U.S., liberals are more likely to favor the UN (80%) and EU (71%) than conservatives (38% and 36%, respectively) [4][image4]. In Germany, those on the left also show higher approval for these organizations compared to those on the right, though the ideological divide is less pronounced than in the U.S. [3][image4].

![Germans favor international organizations more than Americans, with notable ideological differences influencing these views](image1)

Perceptions of Russia also diverge, with Germans viewing it more favorably (37%) than Americans (18%) [1][image1]. This difference is influenced by historical context, as Germans in the former East have a higher favorable opinion of Russia (43%) than those in the former West (33%) [5][image5]. Similarly, ideological divides play a role, with conservatives in both countries more likely to view Russia favorably than liberals, though the gap is wider in the U.S. [3][image4].

![Regional and ideological factors shape German views of Russia, with East Germans holding more favorable opinions](image5)

When it comes to economic powers, Americans and Germans have starkly different perceptions. Half of Americans see the U.S. as the leading economic power, while only 24% of Germans agree. In contrast, 53% of Germans name China as the top economic power, compared to 32% of Americans [7][image2]. This reflects differing national perspectives on economic dominance and global influence. Germans also show slightly higher recognition of the EU as an economic power (14%) than Americans (7%) [7][image2].

![Americans and Germans differ starkly in their views of economic powers, with Americans favoring the U.S. and Germans favoring China](image2)

In summary, Americans and Germans differ in their perceptions of international organizations and economic powers due to ideological divides, regional histories, and national perspectives. Germans tend to view international organizations more favorably, while Americans are more likely to see their own country as the leading economic power. ![Both countries' views are shaped by political ideology and historical context](image4)

American and German perceptions on the necessity of military force and defense spending show notable differences. About eight-in-ten Americans believe it is sometimes necessary to use military force to maintain global order, while only half of Germans agree [4]. Additionally, conservatives in both countries are more likely to justify the use of force than liberals, with nine-in-ten American conservatives and nearly six-in-ten German right-leaning adults supporting this view [6]. When it comes to defense spending, Americans are divided, with half saying European allies should maintain current spending levels, down from 45% in 2017 who favored an increase [1][3]. Germans are similarly split, with about four-in-ten supporting an increase and an equal share favoring maintaining current levels [5]. ![Comparative chart on national defense spending opinions in the U.S. and Germany over time](image1)

Regarding age demographics, younger people in both countries hold more positive views of the U.S.-Germany relationship. In the U.S., 82% of those aged 18-29 view the relationship as good, compared to 73% of those aged 65 and older. Similarly, in Germany, 40% of young people see relations positively, while only 31% of the older generation share this view [2][8]. ![Age group differences in U.S.-Germany relations](image4) These perspectives highlight both generational and cultural divides in attitudes toward military force, defense spending, and bilateral relations.

Americans and Germans hold significantly differing views on military intervention and defense spending. When it comes to defending NATO allies against a potential Russian attack, six-in-ten Americans believe their country should use military force, while an equal share of Germans (60%) believe their country should not [9]. This divergence is further illustrated in the chart, which shows 60% of Americans supporting military intervention compared to only 34% of Germans. ![Americans and Germans differ significantly on military intervention](image1)

Views on defense spending also vary. Americans are divided on whether European allies should increase their defense budgets. In 2019, 35% supported an increase, while 50% favored maintaining current levels and 9% supported a decrease. This marks a shift from 2017, when 45% of Americans favored increased spending by European allies. ![Americans and Germans show differing trends in defense spending opinions](image4) In Germany, public opinion is similarly split, with 40% supporting increased defense spending and 41% favoring the status quo in 2019. Unlike Americans, Germans are less supportive of increased defense budgets compared to 2017, when 32% supported an increase [8][10].

The importance of U.S. military bases in Germany also highlights a divide. While 85% of Americans see these bases as important to U.S. security, only about half of Germans view them as important for their national security [3][5]. Additionally, Americans are more likely to support the use of military force generally, with 80% agreeing it is sometimes necessary, compared to just 50% of Germans [6]. This is further supported by the chart, where 78% of Americans agree with an unspecified military-related statement, versus 47% of Germans. ![Americans are more likely to agree with military-related statements](image3)

Age and political ideology further influence these opinions. In both countries, younger people are more supportive of military-related policies than older generations, as shown by the chart where 82% of Americans aged 18-29 support an unspecified issue, compared to 70% of those 65+. In Germany, 40% of the youngest age group supports the issue, versus 28% of the oldest. ![Age groups in the U.S. and Germany show differing levels of support](image2) Politically, American conservatives are far more likely to support military force (90%) than liberals (65%), and similar ideological divides exist in Germany, with 59% on the right supporting force compared to 33% on the left [4]. Over time, support for increased defense spending among U.S. Republicans has declined from 62% in 2017 to 48% in 2019, while Democrats show a smaller decline from 34% to 28%. ![Political affiliations in the U.S. show declining support for increased defense spending](image5)

In summary, Americans generally favor military intervention and view their bases in Germany as crucial, while Germans are more sceptical of both. Defense spending opinions are similarly divided, with significant shifts in attitudes over time.

American and German opinions on defense spending have shown notable shifts and partisan divides over the years. In the U.S., there has been a decline in the belief that European allies should increase their defense spending. In 2017, 45% of Americans supported this view, but by 2019, only 35% did. Meanwhile, the preference for maintaining current levels of defense spending rose from 37% in 2017 to 50% in 2019 [5]. Partisan differences are evident, with Republicans more likely than Democrats to favor increased defense spending in Europe, though both groups have seen declines in this view since 2017 [8]. ![U.S. opinion trends on European defense spending](image5)

In Germany, public opinion on defense spending has also shifted. In 2017, 51% of Germans were content with current spending levels, but by 2019, this dropped to 41%, with support for increased spending rising from 32% to 40% [7]. Partisan gaps are clear: 51% of CDU/CSU supporters favor increased spending, compared to 41% of SPD supporters and only 28% of Greens supporters [1]. ![German party opinions on defense spending](image4)

Both countries also differ in their views on the U.S. military presence in Germany. While 85% of Americans see these bases as important to U.S. security, only half of Germans agree, with 45% disagreeing [6]. ![U.S. and German views on military bases](image3). Overall, opinions on defense spending and military presence reflect evolving priorities and partisan divisions in both nations.

American and German views on national defense spending have shifted between 2017 and 2019. In the U.S., there has been a decline in the share of Americans who believe European allies should increase their defense spending. In 2017, 45% of Americans supported an increase, but by 2019, this figure dropped to 35%. Conversely, the percentage of Americans favoring maintaining current spending levels rose from 37% in 2017 to 50% in 2019 [1] ![A comparative bar chart showing shifting opinions on defense spending in the U.S. and Germany from 2017 to 2019](image1). 

Partisan differences in the U.S. are notable. Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more likely than Democrats to support increased defense spending in Europe, though support among Republicans has decreased by 14 percentage points from 2017 to 2019. Democrats also showed a modest decline in this view [3] ![A line graph showing declining support for European defense spending increases among Republicans and Democrats from 2017 to 2019](image3). Additionally, Republican-leaning independents overwhelmingly view U.S. military bases in Germany as important to national defense, with 90% supporting this view, compared to about 80% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents [5].

In Germany, public opinion is more divided. About 40% of Germans in 2019 supported increasing defense spending, while 41% favored maintaining current levels. This represents a shift from 2017, when 51% were content with current spending and 32% supported increases [10] ![A comparative bar chart showing shifting opinions on defense spending in the U.S. and Germany from 2017 to 2019](image1). Partisan differences are also evident: CDU/CSU supporters are more likely to favor defense spending increases (51%), while Greens are more skeptical, with only 28% supporting increases. SPD supporters fall in the middle at 41% [9] ![A horizontal bar chart showing varying support for defense spending increases among German political parties](image5).

Regarding the U.S. military presence in Germany, Americans view these bases as much more important to their security than Germans do. While 85% of Americans see them as important, younger Germans (ages 18-29) are particularly skeptical, with 62% believing the bases do not contribute to German national security [6] ![A horizontal bar chart comparing the perceived importance of a subject between U.S. and German respondents](image2) ![A horizontal bar chart showing age-based differences in the perceived importance of a topic in Germany](image4).

In summary, American support for increased European defense spending has declined since 2017, with notable partisan divides, while Germans remain split on whether to increase or maintain defense spending, with significant differences across political parties.

Political affiliations in both the U.S. and Germany significantly shape opinions on increasing defense spending, and these views have evolved over time.  

In the U.S., there is a notable partisan divide. Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more likely than Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents to favor increased defense spending in Europe [3]. However, support among Republicans for European allies to boost their defense budgets has declined by 14 percentage points between 2017 and 2019, with a more modest decline observed among Democrats [3]. ![A line graph showing declining support for increased defense spending among Republicans and Democrats from 2017 to 2019](image5)  

On the other hand, Germans exhibit a different pattern. Supporters of the CDU/CSU are generally in favor of increasing defense spending, while Greens express more skepticism, with only 28% supporting such an increase. SPD supporters fall in between, with 41% favoring higher defense spending [5]. ![A bar chart showing varied levels of support for increased defense spending among German political parties](image3)  

Over time, public opinion on defense spending has shifted in both countries. In the U.S., support for European allies to increase defense spending has declined, as shown in the comparative bar chart. Similarly, in Germany, public opinion has fluctuated, with a dip in 2018 followed by a rebound in 2019 [1]. ![A bar chart showing changing opinions on national defense spending in the U.S. and Germany from 2017 to 2019](image1)  

In summary, political affiliations strongly influence views on defense spending, with Republicans in the U.S. and CDU/CSU supporters in Germany more likely to favor increases, while Democrats and Greens express more skepticism. Over time, support for increased defense spending has declined in the U.S. and fluctuated in Germany.

In Germany, age plays a significant role in shaping perceptions of the importance of U.S. military bases. Younger Germans, particularly those aged 18 to 29, are skeptical, with **62%** believing the bases do not contribute to national security. In contrast, **61%** of Germans aged 65 and older view the bases as important for Germany's defense. This stark divergence highlights a generational divide in attitudes toward the U.S. military presence [9]. ![Older Germans tend to view U.S. military bases as more important than younger Germans.](image5)

In the U.S., political affiliation influences perceptions of foreign policy partners more than views on military bases. Both Democrats and Republicans rank Germany similarly as a foreign policy partner, placing it fifth in importance. However, Republicans are more favorable toward Israel (26%) compared to Democrats (9%), while Democrats prioritize Canada and Mexico more than Republicans [4]. ![Republicans and Democrats have differing preferences for foreign policy partners, particularly regarding Israel, Canada, and Mexico.](image4)

When it comes to the perceived importance of U.S. military bases in Germany, there is bipartisan support in the U.S., with both Republicans and Democrats viewing the presence positively. However, Germans are divided, with **50%** seeing the bases as important and **45%** disagreeing [8]. ![U.S. respondents overwhelmingly view the subject as "Very important," while Germans tend to view it as less important overall.](image3)

Overall, age differences in Germany create a generational split on the importance of U.S. military bases, while political affiliations in the U.S. shape preferences for foreign policy partners without significantly affecting views on the bases in Germany.

Views on U.S. global engagement and handling of international issues vary significantly across political affiliations and educational backgrounds. 

![A bar chart showing varying opinions on U.S. global engagement by political affiliation and education level](image3)  

Political affiliations show a clear divide: 76% of Republicans and Republican-leaning individuals believe the U.S. should let other countries deal with their own problems, while only 23% think the U.S. should handle its own issues [3]. Conversely, 53% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning individuals support the U.S. dealing with its own problems, with 46% favoring helping other nations [8]. This divide deepens along ideological lines, with 64% of liberal Democrats advocating for international aid, compared to 44% of conservative and moderate Democrats [8].

Educational background also plays a role: 60% of postgraduates believe the U.S. should assist other countries, while 49% of college graduates are evenly split. In contrast, clear majorities of those with some college experience (64%) or only a high school diploma (69%) think the U.S. should focus on its own problems [10].

![A bar chart comparing opinions on U.S. handling of international issues across political and educational demographics](image1)  

When evaluating the U.S.’s handling of the coronavirus outbreak, 73% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents are critical, while 71% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents praise the response [9]. This partisan divide extends to education, with more educated Americans being more critical: 66% of postgraduates and 66% of college graduates rate the U.S.’s handling as poor, compared to 59% of those with a high school education or less [3].

In summary, political affiliation and education significantly shape views on U.S. global engagement and handling of international issues, with Republicans and less-educated individuals favoring a focus on domestic problems, while Democrats and more educated individuals are more supportive of international aid and critical of U.S. performance.

Political affiliations and educational backgrounds significantly shape Americans' perceptions of how the U.S. and China have handled the COVID-19 pandemic. 

When it comes to the U.S., opinions are starkly divided along party lines. Around 73% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents are critical of the U.S.’s response, while 71% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents praise it [3]. This partisan divide is further illustrated in the bar chart, which shows that 76% of Republicans/Lean Republicans view the U.S. response as "Only fair/poor," compared to 54% of Democrats/Lean Democrats [image5]. 

Education also plays a role in shaping these views. More educated Americans are more critical of the U.S. response, with around two-thirds of those with a postgraduate degree and six-in-ten college graduates saying the U.S. has done a poor job. In contrast, only about four-in-ten of those with a high school degree or less share this view [2]. This trend is reflected in the bar chart, where 62% of those with postgraduate education and 66% of college graduates rate the U.S. response as "Only fair/poor," compared to 62% of those with a high school education or less [image3].

In contrast, perceptions of China’s handling of the pandemic show less variation by education. Majorities across all educational groups agree that China has not handled the pandemic well [4]. However, older Americans, who generally have less favorable attitudes toward China, are more critical, with 69% of those aged 65 and older saying China has done a fair or poor job, compared to 59% of those under 30 [7]. The bar chart also highlights this, showing that 69% of those aged 65+ rate China’s response as "Only fair/poor," compared to 59% of those aged 18-29 [image5].

In summary, political affiliations deeply influence Americans' views on the U.S.’s handling of COVID-19, with Republicans more likely to support the response and Democrats more critical. Education further divides these perceptions, with more educated Americans being more critical of the U.S. response. For China, education plays a minimal role, but age and pre-existing attitudes significantly shape perceptions. ![Political affiliations significantly influence perceptions of the U.S. and China's COVID-19 response.](image5) ![Education shapes critical views of the U.S. response, with more educated Americans being more critical.](image3)

Political affiliations significantly shape perceptions of how the U.S. and China have handled the COVID-19 pandemic. When it comes to the U.S., there is a stark partisan divide. While 71% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents believe the U.S. has done a good or excellent job, only 27% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents share this view [2][8]. This 44-point gap highlights how deeply political ideology influences evaluations of the U.S. response. ![Partisan divide in U.S. handling of COVID-19](image2)

In contrast, opinions on China’s handling of the pandemic show a more nuanced partisan split. While majorities across both parties criticize China’s response, Republicans are far more likely to hold this view, with 80% of conservative Republicans saying China has not handled the crisis well [9]. Democrats, while still critical, are somewhat less harsh in their judgments. This pattern underscores how partisan bias extends beyond domestic evaluations to assessments of foreign countries.

The belief that the U.S. can learn from other countries also plays a role. Those who think the U.S. can glean lessons from abroad are more likely to critique the U.S. response, with only 44% rating it as good or excellent, compared to 63% of those who think the U.S. cannot learn much from overseas [5]. This sentiment is further illustrated in the chart, where respondents who believe the U.S. can learn from other countries are notably more positive about the responses of countries like Germany and South Korea compared to those who do not share this view. ![Impact of belief in learning from other countries on U.S. response evaluations](image1)

Overall, political affiliation strongly influences perceptions of both the U.S. and China’s handling of the pandemic, with Republicans more likely to approve of the U.S. response and criticize China, while Democrats are more critical of the U.S. and slightly less harsh toward China.

Perceptions of the U.S.'s ability to learn from other countries in handling the coronavirus vary significantly across political affiliations. For instance, 67% of liberal Democrats believe the U.S. can learn a great deal from other nations, compared to only 25% of conservative Republicans [5]. This partisan divide is also reflected in broader comparisons, with 60% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents saying the U.S. can learn a great deal, while only 28% of Republicans and Republican leaners share this view [6]. Republicans who do believe the U.S. can learn from other nations are more likely to say other countries are dealing with the pandemic effectively, a pattern mirrored among Democrats [8]. 

![The image is a bar chart showing the perceptions of some variable by different demographic groups.](image1)

Trust in international organizations like the WHO and the EU also follows partisan lines. While 86% of liberal Democrats trust information from the WHO at least a fair amount, only 27% of conservative Republicans feel the same [10]. Similarly, trust in the EU is higher among those with higher education levels, with 78% of Americans with a postgraduate degree trusting EU information, compared to 72% of college graduates [3]. This trust disparity is further illustrated in charts showing trust levels among political groups, where Liberal Democrats exhibit the highest trust in the WHO (86%) and the EU (79%), while Conservative Republicans have the lowest (27% and 49%, respectively) [image2].

![The image is a chart showing the trust levels among different political groups for the WHO, EU, and the Chinese government.](image2)

Education levels also influence these perceptions and trust. Those with postgraduate degrees are more likely to trust information from the WHO and the EU, with 70% of postgraduates trusting the WHO at least a fair amount, including 33% who trust it a great deal [2]. This trend is consistent across other education levels, as shown in charts where higher education correlates with higher trust in international organizations [image3][image4]. 

In summary, perceptions of the U.S.'s ability to learn from other countries and trust in international organizations like the WHO and EU are heavily influenced by political affiliation and education level, with Democrats and those holding higher degrees expressing greater openness and trust.

Views about the future influence of the U.S., EU, and China vary significantly based on political affiliation and education level. Partisan divides are particularly stark, with Republicans and Democrats holding contrasting perspectives on the impact of the coronavirus outbreak on global influence.

For the U.S., Republicans are about twice as likely as Democrats to believe the country’s international influence will strengthen post-crisis, while Democrats are roughly four times more likely to expect it to weaken [3]. Internal divisions also exist among Democrats, with liberal supporters 20 percentage points more likely than conservatives and moderates to foresee a decline in U.S. influence [3]. ![The chart shows partisan differences in opinions about the future influence of the U.S., EU, and China, with color-coded categories for "More," "About the same," and "Less."](image3)

Education level further influences these views. Americans with higher education are more likely to believe the U.S.’s global influence will recede, with 45% of postgraduate degree holders holding this view [10]. ![The bar chart displays survey results based on education level and political affiliation, showing percentages for "More," "About the same," and "Less."](image1)

Regarding the EU, trust levels increase significantly across political affiliations, from 49% among Conservative Republicans to 79% among Liberal Democrats [2]. This suggests that political affiliation heavily influences perceptions of the EU’s future role. ![The image is a chart showing trust levels among different political groups for the WHO, EU, and the Chinese government, with percentages increasing from Conservative Republicans to Liberal Democrats.](image2)

For China, half of Americans believe its global influence will decline post-outbreak, with Republicans and older Americans more likely to hold this view [1][6]. Education also plays a role, as higher-educated individuals are more inclined to predict a reduction in China’s influence. ![The bar chart breaks down survey results by race, age, and political affiliation, showing percentages for "More," "About the same," and "Less."](image5)

In summary, political affiliation and education level significantly shape views on the future influence of the U.S., EU, and China, with Republicans and less-educated individuals more likely to predict a decline in China’s influence and a boost in U.S. influence, while Democrats and higher-educated individuals foresee the opposite.

Predictions about the global influence of the U.S. and China after the coronavirus outbreak vary significantly across demographic and political groups. For the U.S., Republicans are about twice as likely as Democrats to believe that the country’s international influence will strengthen, while Democrats, particularly liberal ones, are more likely to foresee a decline [1]. ![Education level and political affiliation influence perceptions of U.S. global power](image1) Additionally, Americans with higher levels of education are more inclined to think the U.S.’s global influence will recede [9].

On the other hand, views on China’s global influence also show notable divides. Half of Americans believe China’s influence will decline after the pandemic, with Republicans and older Americans more likely to hold this view compared to Democrats and younger adults [4, 10]. ![Age and political affiliation shape opinions on China’s global power](image3) For instance, 63% of Republicans and those leaning Republican think China’s influence will diminish, compared to 40% of Democrats [4]. ![Race, age, and political affiliation affect perceptions of China’s global influence](image4) 

Overall, partisan and age divides are particularly pronounced, with Republicans and older Americans expressing more negative views on China’s future global standing, while Democrats and younger adults are less pessimistic [7]. ![Comparative views on the U.S., EU, and China’s global influence post-pandemic](image2) These differences highlight how political affiliation, age, and education shape perceptions of global power dynamics in the aftermath of the coronavirus outbreak.

Americans generally hold a negative view of China’s handling of the coronavirus outbreak, with nearly two-thirds stating that the country has not done a good job, including 37% who believe it has done a poor job [3]. This sentiment is reflected in the bar chart, which shows that only 7% rate China’s performance as excellent, while 37% rate it as poor ![China's performance ratings](image5). Trust in information from the Chinese government is also low, with few Americans believing it has handled the outbreak well [1].

Regarding China’s future influence on the global stage, 50% of Americans predict it will decline after the pandemic, while 31% believe it will remain the same and 17% think it will grow [2]. This is visually represented in the bar chart where "Less influence" is the longest bar at 50 ![China's future influence](image3). Partisan differences are stark: 60% of Republicans believe China’s influence will diminish, compared to only 40% of Democrats [5]. Older Americans are also more likely than younger adults to predict a decline in China’s global standing [5].

Partisan divides further shape these perceptions. Republicans, particularly conservative Republicans, are significantly more critical of China’s handling of the outbreak, with 80% expressing negative views [7]. Similarly, while both Democrats and Republicans hold unfavorable opinions of China, Republicans are more likely to have negative attitudes [4]. 

In summary, Americans largely view China’s coronavirus response poorly and predict a decline in its global influence, with Republicans being more critical and pessimistic compared to Democrats.

Partisan views on the U.S. role in solving world problems and its influence after the coronavirus outbreak show significant differences, particularly between Republicans and Democrats. According to the data, Republicans are more likely to believe the U.S. does "too much" in addressing global challenges, with 62% holding this view in 2020, up from 52% in 2013 [5]. Conversely, only 26% of Democrats share this perspective, marking a stark partisan divide [5].

![Partisan views on U.S. role in solving world problems from 2013 to 2020](image4)  
The line graph illustrates the growing partisan gap over time, with Republicans increasingly believing the U.S. does "too much," while Democrats show a contrasting trend.

When it comes to the U.S. influence after the coronavirus outbreak, the divide is equally pronounced. Liberal Democrats are far more likely to believe the U.S. will emerge with less global influence (56%) compared to conservative Republicans (8%) [7]. This reflects broader skepticism among Democrats about the U.S.'s international standing post-pandemic.

![Partisan views on U.S. influence after the coronavirus outbreak](image2)  
The chart highlights the sharp differences in perceptions between political groups, with liberal Democrats being significantly more pessimistic about the U.S.'s global influence.

Education also plays a role in these views, as those with higher education levels are more likely to believe the U.S. can learn from other countries and to trust international organizations like the WHO [4][9]. These findings underscore the deep partisan and ideological divides in opinions about the U.S.'s global role and its influence in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak.

Partisan views on the U.S.'s ability to learn from other countries and its role in global affairs during the coronavirus pandemic show significant differences, particularly between Democrats and Republicans. A majority of Americans, 84%, believe the U.S. can learn either a great deal or a fair amount from other countries about ways to slow the spread of the coronavirus [1]. However, this belief is more pronounced among Democrats and those with higher levels of education. For instance, 67% of liberal Democrats think the U.S. can learn a great deal from other nations, compared to just 25% of conservative Republicans [4]. ![Partisan differences on learning from other countries](image5)

Education also plays a role, as those with postgraduate degrees (56%) and college graduates (50%) are more likely to believe the U.S. can learn a great deal from other countries, compared to those with a high school education or less (41%) [9]. ![Education level impacts perceptions of learning from other countries](image1)

When it comes to the U.S.'s role in global affairs, there is a stark divide. While 64% of liberal Democrats believe the U.S. should help other countries deal with their problems, only 22% of conservative Republicans share this view [10]. Additionally, 56% of liberal Democrats think the U.S. will have less influence in world affairs after the pandemic, compared to just 8% of conservative Republicans [6]. ![Partisan views on U.S. global influence post-pandemic](image5)

Overall, Democrats are more inclined to advocate for international collaboration and believe the U.S. can learn significantly from other countries, while Republicans are more skeptical of these ideas.

Views on whether the U.S. should deal with its own problems or help other countries vary significantly across political affiliations and educational levels. 

For political affiliations, 76% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents believe the U.S. should focus on its own problems, while only 23% think it should assist other countries. Among Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents, the split is more even, with 46% favoring dealing with domestic issues and 53% supporting helping other nations. This divide is further pronounced along ideological lines within the Democratic Party: 64% of liberal Democrats advocate for aiding other countries, compared to 44% of conservative and moderate Democrats [4][6].

Educational attainment also plays a role in shaping these views. Postgraduates are the most supportive of helping other nations, with 60% in favor, while those with some college experience or only a high school diploma are more likely to prioritize domestic issues, with 64% and 69%, respectively, saying the U.S. should focus on its own problems. College graduates are evenly split on the issue, with 49% on each side [9].

![The image is a bar chart showing the percentages of various demographics' views on whether the U.S. should deal with its own problems or let other countries deal with their own problems as best they can.](image1)

In conclusion, Republicans and those with lower educational levels are more likely to prioritize domestic issues, while Democrats and individuals with higher education are more supportive of assisting other countries.

Perceptions of the U.S. role in solving world problems vary significantly by political affiliation and have evolved over time. Currently, a majority of Republicans (62%) believe the U.S. does too much to help solve world problems, with only 8% saying it does too little and 29% stating it does the right amount. In contrast, a plurality of Democrats (48%) feel the U.S. does too little, while 26% each believe it does the right amount or too much [3]. 

![A line graph showing the rise in the perception that the U.S. does "Too much" in solving world problems, particularly among Republicans, from 2013 to 2020](image3)

This partisan divide has grown more pronounced over the years. In telephone surveys from previous years, the gap between Republicans and Democrats was far less stark [6]. However, by 2020, the difference became more evident, as illustrated in the line graph showing a steady increase in the belief that the U.S. does "Too much" (orange line) among Republicans, while Democrats' views remained more divided [image3].

![A bar chart showing that 76% of Republicans believe the U.S. should deal with its own problems, compared to 46% of Democrats](image2)

Additionally, when asked whether the U.S. should focus on its own problems or help other countries, 76% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents prefer the U.S. to address its own issues, while 46% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents hold the same view [image2]. Among Democrats, ideological differences are also notable: 64% of liberal Democrats support helping other countries, compared to 44% of conservative and moderate Democrats [7].

These trends highlight a deepening ideological split in how Americans, particularly along party lines, perceive the U.S. role in global problem-solving.

Views on U.S. global engagement and dealing with domestic issues vary significantly by political affiliation and educational attainment. 

Among Republicans, 62% believe the U.S. does too much to help solve global problems, with only 8% saying it does too little and 29% stating it does the right amount [3]. This sentiment is further emphasized by the fact that 76% of Republicans and Republican-leaning individuals believe the U.S. should deal with its own problems and let other countries manage as best they can [image1]. In contrast, Democrats are more divided: 48% think the U.S. does too little to help solve world problems, while 26% each believe it does too much or the right amount [3]. Additionally, a majority of Democrats (53%) support the U.S. helping other countries deal with their problems, though this view is more prevalent among liberal Democrats (64%) than conservative and moderate Democrats (44%) [5].

Educational attainment also plays a significant role. Postgraduates are the most supportive of global engagement, with 60% advocating for helping other countries, while those with no more than a high school diploma are the least supportive, with only 29% favoring such assistance [image1]. Education also influences perceptions of the U.S.’s handling of global issues, as more educated individuals are more critical of the U.S.’s performance, with around two-thirds of postgraduates and six-in-ten college graduates saying the U.S. has done a poor job [9].

![A bar chart showing the percentages of various demographics' views on whether the U.S. should deal with its own problems or let other countries deal with their own problems as best they can.](image1)

In summary, Republicans and those with lower educational attainment are more inclined to focus on domestic issues, while Democrats and those with higher education levels are more supportive of U.S. global engagement.

Americans' confidence in President Biden's ability to deal effectively with China is relatively low compared to their concerns about specific issues in the U.S.-China relationship. Only 53% of Americans express confidence in Biden’s ability to handle China [2], which is the lowest among six foreign policy issues tested [1]. In contrast, Americans perceive several issues related to China as highly serious. For example, 65% view cyberattacks from China as a very serious problem, and 52% say the same about China’s growing military power [10]. 

![A bar chart showing levels of confidence in Biden's ability to handle foreign policy issues, with the lowest confidence (53%) in dealing with China.](image1)

The disparity is further highlighted in how Americans prioritize these concerns. Limiting China's power and influence ranks as a higher priority for many, with 63% of Americans viewing it as important [image2]. Additionally, 91% of Americans consider cyberattacks from China at least somewhat serious, and 86% feel the same about China’s military power [image4].

![A bar chart illustrating the seriousness of various issues related to China, with cyberattacks and military power among the top concerns.](image4)

This suggests that while Americans are highly concerned about issues like cyberattacks, military power, and job losses to China [9], their confidence in Biden’s ability to manage these challenges is notably lower than their confidence in his handling of other foreign policy issues [2]. The combination of heightened concern and limited confidence underscores the complexity of the U.S.-China relationship in the public’s perception.

Confidence in President Biden’s ability to deal effectively with China varies significantly across demographic groups. Overall, 53% of Americans express confidence in Biden on this issue, the lowest among the six foreign policy issues tested [2]. However, partisan differences are stark, with 83% of Democrats or leaners expressing confidence compared to just 19% of Republicans or leaners. Conservative Republicans show the least confidence at 10%, while moderate or liberal Republicans are slightly higher at 30%. Among Democrats, confidence remains high across ideological lines, with 86% of conservative/moderate Democrats and 81% of liberal Democrats expressing trust in Biden [3].

![Levels of confidence across demographic groups vary significantly, with Republicans showing the least confidence.](image2)

Women (59%) are more confident than men (48%), and Black (82%) and Hispanic adults (70%) express higher confidence than White adults (43%). Additionally, those with a college degree (60%) are more confident than those without (50%) [10]. Older Americans also show heightened concerns about China-related issues, with those aged 65+ more likely to view these as very serious problems compared to younger age groups [4].

Americans express substantial concern about various issues in the U.S.-China relationship. The most pressing concerns include cyberattacks from China (65% very serious), China’s growing military power (52% very serious), the loss of U.S. jobs to China (53% very serious), and China’s human rights policies (50% very serious) [5]. The U.S. trade deficit with China is also a significant concern, particularly among those with lower levels of education [6].

![Americans are most concerned about cyberattacks, China’s military power, job losses, and human rights policies.](image3)

These concerns are further reflected in the priority lists, where limiting China’s power and influence ranks higher among Republicans (63%) than Democrats (36%) [1]. Overall, the data shows a combination of partisan, demographic, and issue-specific factors shaping confidence in Biden and concerns about China.

Confidence in President Joe Biden’s ability to deal effectively with China varies significantly across different demographic and political groups. Women (59%) are more confident than men (48%), and Black (82%) and Hispanic adults (70%) express higher confidence compared to White adults (43%). Additionally, those with a college degree (60%) are more confident than those without one (50%) [6]. Politically, the divide is stark: 83% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents have confidence in Biden, while only 19% of Republicans and Republican leaners share this sentiment. Conservative Republicans (10%) have even less confidence than moderate or liberal Republicans (30%) [4]. ![Political affiliations show a wide gap in confidence levels, with Democrats significantly more confident in Biden’s ability to handle China than Republicans](image3)

When it comes to concerns about China, several issues are perceived as very serious by Americans. Over half consider cyberattacks from China (65%), the loss of U.S. jobs to China (53%), China’s growing military power (52%), and China’s human rights policies (50%) as major problems. These concerns have grown over the past year, with a 6-point increase in the share of Americans who see job losses to China as a very serious issue [7][9]. ![Bar chart showing the most serious concerns about China, including cyberattacks, job losses, and military power](image4)

Partisanship also plays a role in the perception of these issues. Republicans and Republican-leaning individuals are more likely than Democrats to view most China-related problems as very serious. For instance, the percentage of Republicans concerned about the loss of U.S. jobs to China increased from 52% in 2020 to 66% in 2021, while Democrats’ concern decreased slightly from 43% to 42% [2]. ![Line graphs highlighting partisan differences in serious concerns about China](image2) 

Overall, confidence in Biden’s handling of China is heavily influenced by political affiliation, education level, and race, while concerns about China’s actions, particularly cyberattacks and job losses, are widely regarded as critical issues by Americans.

Confidence levels in President Joe Biden’s ability to deal effectively with China vary significantly across demographic groups. Among the total population, 53% express confidence, while 46% do not [4]. Partisan differences are stark: 83% of Democrats and Democratic leaners have confidence in Biden, compared to only 19% of Republicans and Republican leaners [3]. Conservative Republicans have even less confidence at 10%, while moderate or liberal Republicans show slightly higher confidence at 30% [3].

![Demographic confidence levels in Biden’s handling of China are illustrated in this bar graph.](image1)

Ethnic, age, and education levels also influence confidence. The bar graph shows varied percentages across groups like White, Black, Hispanic, age brackets, and education levels, with specific breakdowns indicating higher or lower confidence based on these demographics [image1].

Major concerns Americans have regarding China are highlighted in the survey results. Cyberattacks from China evoke the most concern, with 65% considering them a very serious problem [7]. Other significant issues include the loss of U.S. jobs to China (53% very serious), China’s growing military power (52% very serious), and China’s policies on human rights (50% very serious) [10]. Additionally, the U.S. trade deficit with China is seen as a very serious problem by 43%, with higher concern among those with less than a college degree [5].

![Concerns about China-related issues, including cyberattacks and military power, are detailed in this bar chart.](image2)

When broken down by political affiliation, Republicans tend to express greater concern than Democrats on most issues. For example, the share of Republicans viewing the loss of U.S. jobs to China as a very serious problem increased by 14 percentage points from 2020 to 2021, while Democrats showed no significant change [9].

In summary, confidence in Biden’s ability to handle China varies widely by demographics, with Democrats expressing much higher confidence than Republicans. Americans are particularly concerned about cyberattacks, job losses, China’s military power, and human rights policies.

American perceptions of China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic and its respect for personal freedoms are overwhelmingly negative. Regarding the pandemic, **54% of Americans believe China has done a "bad job," with 28% describing it as "very bad"** [7]. This sentiment is stronger among Republicans (71%) compared to Democrats (39%), and among those with less than a college degree compared to college-educated individuals [8]. Similarly, **90% of Americans think the Chinese government does not respect the personal freedoms of its people**, a perspective consistent across age, education, and political groups [6]. ![A bar graph showing 90% of Americans believe China does not respect personal freedoms](image1)

When it comes to U.S. priorities in its relations with China, **70% of Americans believe the U.S. should prioritize promoting human rights, even if it harms economic relations**, while only 26% think the U.S. should focus on economic relations without addressing human rights [1]. ![A bar graph illustrating U.S. priorities in relations with China](image1)

In summary, Americans are critical of both China’s pandemic response and its human rights record, and they overwhelmingly support prioritizing human rights in U.S.-China relations.

Political affiliations in the U.S. significantly influence perceptions of balancing human rights and economic relations with China. Among Republicans, particularly conservative Republicans, there is a strong inclination to prioritize human rights over economic ties, with 77% supporting this stance [6]. Moderate or liberal Republicans also lean towards human rights, though less emphatically, at 66% [6]. 

![Conservative Republicans strongly prioritize human rights over economic relations](image3)

On the other hand, Democrats show a similar prioritization of human rights, with 69% overall supporting this approach [6]. Liberal Democrats are the most adamant, with 76% favoring human rights promotion even if it harms economic relations, while conservative or moderate Democrats are slightly less emphatic at 64% [6].

![Liberal Democrats prioritize human rights, with 76% favoring it over economic relations](image3)
